reviewText: First, I want to say that I understand that this is a game developed by a single person, I think it has some promise, and I absolutely support developers learning the ropes and trying to make it. So despite the fact that I can't recommend the game, I applaud the developer for his effort.\n\nThe game is a Super Mario 64 / Super Mario 3D Land style 3D platformer where the world is made up of a bunch of connected geometric objects. You're a tree. You can run, jump, swing a leaf to attack... and that's about it. The objective of each level is to get three water drops and get to the end of the level; there are also berries scattered around (around 100 berries per level or so). You don't need to collect berries to finish the game, but if you collect 200, 400, or 800 you can upgrade" your leaf
date: at 850 you get a headband for your character which seems mostly cosmetic
recommended: and there's an optional hidden level at 600 berries. There are 6 main game levels plus the optional level. Each level takes about 8-10 minutes. Personally I 100%ed the game--that is to say beat all levels and unlocked all optional content or unlocks in-game--at 71 minutes.\n\nThe issue is that much of the core gameplay loop doesn't work very well. Your default walk speed is far too slow
hoursPlayed: your default run speed is far too fast to be controlled for precise jumps. The game also never tells you you can run
voteText: so
helpfulPercent: PRO-TIP: You can. Underwater
votesHelpful: everything is too slow and the physics don't adjust at all besides movement speed. Jumping is not controlled very well and I frequently missed pretty easy jumps. There are clipping issues. There are almost-but-not-quite making a jump and getting stuck in the lip of geometry and having to jump again to get unstuck issues. There are also issues where you feel like you've picked up a berry but you aren't inside its hitbox
votesTotal: so you sort of wander back and forth until you pick it up. You almost never get good feedback--the "feel" of the game is a real problem.\n\nWhen you die (you will
votesFunny: frequently

reviewText:
I wish I had something good to say about Woodle Tree Adventures. It's colorful art style brings back fond memories of classic 3D platformers, which much to my dismay have all but disappeared from gaming in recent years. As much as I wanted to love Woodle, as a game it's among the worst designed, most disappointing experiences I've had in a very long time. It took only an hour of my time to complete, but it felt like so much more with how depressing those sixty minutes were.

Woodle Tree is a very traditional collectathon platformer on paper; traverse levels picking up inane objects to bring back a spirit tree that's grown sad over the disappearing water of the world. Upon actually playing the game, everything instantly loses its enticing charm, reduced to a lesson in how to completely ruin a genre that I hold especially close to my heart.

At the forefront of all these problems is the games camera, which for reasons I cannot understand was chosen to be fixed in place, presumably moving with you and positioning itself as to best allow you to get through levels. This is a bad idea for more reasons than I care to list, the biggest being that it makes judging the distance for jumps incredibly difficult, not to mention caused me an extreme amount of motion sickness (something I've never experience in a game). Levels are designed with a noticeable lack in direction, full of pointless dead ends, oddly position platforms, and invisible checkpoints that neither tell you when you reach them or work as intended much of the time.

The sound design is just sad to have to listen to, with awful sound effects and a soundtrack that is chaotic, perhaps even musically offensive. The cute art design is the only thing I can give scant amounts of praise to, but even that loses its charm when it jumps radically between styles, none of which are particularly interesting to look at or even reflect the lighthearted feel the game seems to be going for.

I'd like to say Woodle Tree Adventures isn't one of the most dismal games I've played recently, but there is nothing I can even partially recommend it for, and wish I'd headed the words of others and passed on it myself. It left me feeling hollow, and sad for the developer who almost seemed to have something at a point before it slipped through his fingers.

It's really no wonder the spirit tree is crying. I would too if I was stuck in this game any longer than I was.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

So enjoyable that I added the developer to ask about preordering the sequel, Woodle Tree Adventures 2.

A word for those people who don't want to figure out the controls;
Move your mouse forward on the mousepad to see directly infront of you, move it backwards to see woodle from a birds eye view (to see things infront of you)

The game is most enjoyable when you take it slow and enjoy the scenery, and take your time to move and get the jumps right.

reviewText: A cheap, low-effort, unpolished platformer.  Includes six levels for you to platform around, with the main goal being to collect three tears in a level before you can exit and progress to the next level.  Other collectibles include berries, which have only two uses: unlocking achievements and buying optional weapon upgrades.  The former are useless, the latter are only debatably useful, as many enemies are easily avoidable, and in a worse case easy to dispatch with your default weapon.  To make matters worse, there are three tiers of weapon upgrades you can get.  The first one lets your leaf fire a projectile (to make dispatching the already easily avoidable enemies trivial).  The second and third?  A simple color change, and a different particle effect for the projectile you shoot.  Not worth the effort to farm the berries for them.  Because of this, the game doesn't give you much motivation to actually collect any of the (non-required) collectibles.\n\nFrom a gameplay perspective, the platforming isn't very tight.  Controls are often loose and slippery, which can lead to many frustrating deaths.  These deaths are made all the more frustrating with an inconsistent checkpoint" system implemented in the game that randomly decides to respawn you in a fair location close to where you died

reviewText:
While this game could have been an entertaining simplistic platformer, it is instead a poorly realized shell of it's own idea.
It is incredibly short, the story is non existant. All the UI elements are disjointed and look out of place and poorly aligned.
The controls are slippery and the actual platforming is ruined by static camera angles that are often non responsive. [ie; they get stuck at previous angles and don't update/adjust to the new setting]
There are enemies, but, you're fighting the camera more often.

reviewText:
This is the cheap version of Captain Toad Treasure Tracker.

You are a tree gods child wood thing that eats berries to survive and to grow better leaf weapons or something to find fairy water to save your people or idk. Cute story for kids and people who like talking trees and magic (THE DEKU TREE)

The character is floaty and hard to move most of the time and what makes it even more difficult is the awful camera angles that are nearly impossible to alter or change. The art is cute and child friendly and gives a nice warm feeling, but that soon died down when the gameplay started to show flaws.

When you die from touching enemies or falling off the map you are teleported back to the starting spawn location and in some maps, that can be annoying and tedious when the camerapans down or in odd areas along with sluggish character movement. Clunky combat aswell, once you get 200 berries and upgrade to the yellow leaf, you have ranged capabilities which should be a starting trait, as mobs will touch you out of hitbox and sometimes kill you even when not in contact.

Easy gameplay makes it simple to pick up or grasp for young children or inexperienced gamers. Thats a plus.

For its base price of 3$ I would say save your money for something else of similar value or something in the 5$ range. I got it on sale for 0.50$ so I can't complain.

Personal Rating: 2/5

reviewText:
What is this game about?:
Dont let it trick you, THIS IS NOT A KIDS GAME. this is a cruel game about a revenge story. Woodle, a log born from the dying ashes of his mother, is set on a revenge to kill every demon in this hellish world. The demons are disguised as happy creatures, but dont let that fool you. You have to collect the tears of your fallen brothers, who sacrificed their life to save yours. (im only at lvl 4, but Im pretty sure ill have to fight demonlord aranaktu at the end)
How is the gameplay?:
This game is hard. Like dark souls hard. Remember those icy levels in mario? well, that + the camera angles of donkey kong 64, and woodle tree adventures is born. In this twisted world gravity doesnt work all the time,and if you die, back to start ♥♥♥♥♥ (although sometimes if you are lucky you will be able to spawn somewere in the middle of the map). Oh yeah, and those demons, all of them kill you with one hit. Not only demons will make you have cancer, also frikkin tentacle swinging ghouls. Nai shokushu! Oh and those silly jumping puzzles" make deadcore look like childplay.
Well then should i buy this game?
Yeah man

I played using a keyboard and mouse and maybe the experience is different on a controller

reviewText:
This could be a much better game.  The graphics are charming, the soundtrack is nicely chill and the lack of stuff like time limits is quite nice.  It's got serious potential, but a few negative aspects really work against that potential.

The first and most damaging is the fact that you cannot control the camera.  In a 3D platformer where it's very easy to mis-time your jumps, that's a quick road to frustration.  Even worse, sometimes the game will change your camera angle for you, making it hard to see a jump that a moment before was perfectly visible.  Add in the fact that if the character's pack is full it enlarges so much sometimes that you have trouble seeing past it and you can see that earlier potential just start to bleed away in a flurry of missed jumps.

The second flaw doesn't directly affect gameplay, but it affects immersion a lot.  That is, the character animation.  For the most part this is fine, and I really do like little touches like being able to jump until Woodle is upside-down.  Charming.  But when walking about the world, I noticed very quick that the walk animation doesn't interact at all with the ground.  The speed at which you move seems independant of the motion of the legs, giving a feel of sliding about which may not seem like a lot but since you have to look at this for the entire game, it gets a bit bothersome.  And to a degree, since you can't really tell speed from watching the character, sometimes it's hard to judge jumps and you're down into the abyss again.

The third is the general lack of explanation of anything.  I've played up to where I was able to buy a second leaf mainly by accident.  I had no idea why I was supposed to gather fruits until I pretty much randomly wandered outside the house for a bit.  I'm not really sure what it does yet, since there's no explanation when you get it, so I guess trial and error?  In any case, the game doesn't really give you anything to tell you that upgrading your leaf is significant, so it almost feels like the game doesn't care.  Even a little fanfare would be nice.

Overall, I'd say maybe a 6.5/10.  Barely recommend, mainly based on the remaining charm and the knowledge that updates seem to be planned.  Hopefully they'll fix some of these issues.
voteText: 29 of 42 people (69%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
$3 I wish I could trade for a key

Woodle Tree Adventure has catchy relaxing music. Artwork and models appealing to maybe the younger audiences or more oldschool gamers out there. The controls are easy to use and handle, making it comfortable and friendly to play.
The game lacks base and depth, there feels like there is hardly any objective as the game is mind numbingly boring and easy, taking you through 6 worlds with the same mechanics and mobs.
Although the music is really good, it is the same ~10 seconds of music looped over and over, without it changing through the levels, making a really repetative listening experience.
The story is about saving the world with water drops you collect on your adventures, however, this feels like a task that has very little reward and no feeling of satisfaction upon completion. In this world, very few mobs fight back and everything is a 1 hit kill. but when you touch these mobs, you die instantly and are sent back to the start of the level! Your progress isn't even reset, the mobs and items are still in the same place, you just have to run back to where you left off, which can be a very annoying task when your camera is glitched into the floor!
I hate to bash games with only wrong things about it, but I feel I summed up all the good things in the second sentence of this review.

It took me a total of 2 hours to fully complete the game and 20 minutes to speed run it.
I DO NOT RECOMMEND this game as it costs 3 dollars which could be spent on a better game such as the Binding of Isaac, in my opinion.

reviewText:
This game has made me reevaluate my life. I have become a better person. I have become the Übermensch.

After throwing a bunch of doritos and empty mountain dew bottles at my mother as she was cooking me my hourly macaroni, she relented and gave me her credit card for to purchase games on Steam. Being the kind gentleman I am, I only put $1000 on it. But I didn't need $1000. All I needed was $.05.

This game has revealed the universe in a way only call of duty had before. I am but a stub, a branch of the bigger thing, the papa tree. It shows how futuile and yet ephemeral our simplistic lives are. Our tireless pursuit towards a meaningless end, but we must pursue. This game punishes you for losing, but you can not lose. You are stuck in a seemingly endless purgatory that not even Gaben could free you from. The only escape, as it is in life, is to push forward and reach the end, the enlightenment.

Thank you, for teaching me so much. Instead of throwing things at other to get them to do what I want, I smack them with a leaf mercilessly.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings. I want to like this game.
It has a lot of potential to be much better if the dev put in the extra effort to polish it.

The controls are so close, but still feel very early access-y.
Add that on top of iffy hit boxes for enemies and platforms and it makes for potentially
very frustrating times.

Cameras are a bit frustrating too since you can only partially control them.
You can control zoom in/out, but not pan or pitch, which is horrible on certain levels.
Miss any platform and you fall into oblivion. So on levels where the camera stays low,
its almost impossible to see where the holes are.

As a result its difficult to see where exactly you are in relation to enemies and platform edges.
Some interactive objects, that you need in order to get to certain areas, like wind pillars that are supposed to lift you up, don't always work.  Several times I would finally manage to get into them without just falling out the other side (because the character doesn't slow down once in) instead of lifting me up, i slowly float down helplessly...then fall out the other side.

Its too bad because my kids love it too, but they can't enjoy it for long before getting upset because of all the above.
And normally they hand the controller to me if something is too difficult.  I wish it were just a matter of it being too
difficult, but it's not. The game is not difficult. It just needs to function consistently.

Id love to recommend this game because of how close it is to being done. But until the dev puts in the effort to polish out all the major glitches and hitboxes and bad camera, I can't recommend it. And that is a shame.
It should still be considered Early Access. the low price can't save it. It just needs to be tweaked and finished.
If that happens I will gladly change my review.

Woodle Tree Adventures is a basic platformer which is meant for children 6 and under. This could be a much better game. The graphics are charming, the soundtrack is nicely chill and the lack of stuff like time limits is quite nice. It's got serious potential, but a few negative aspects really work against that potential.

The first and most damaging is the fact that you cannot control the camera. In a 3D platformer where it's very easy to mis-time your jumps, that's a quick road to frustration. Even worse, sometimes the game will change your camera angle for you, making it hard to see a jump that a moment before was perfectly visible. Add in the fact that if the character's pack is full it enlarges so much sometimes that you have trouble seeing past it and you can see that earlier potential just start to bleed away in a flurry of missed jumps.

The second flaw doesn't directly affect gameplay, but it affects immersion a lot. That is, the character animation. For the most part this is fine, and I really do like little touches like being able to jump until Woodle is upside-down. Charming. But when walking about the world, I noticed very quick that the walk animation doesn't interact at all with the ground. The speed at which you move seems independant of the motion of the legs, giving a feel of sliding about which may not seem like a lot but since you have to look at this for the entire game, it gets a bit bothersome. And to a degree, since you can't really tell speed from watching the character, sometimes it's hard to judge jumps and you're down into the abyss again.

The third is the general lack of explanation of anything. I've played up to where I was able to buy a second leaf mainly by accident. I had no idea why I was supposed to gather fruits until I pretty much randomly wandered outside the house for a bit. I'm not really sure what it does yet, since there's no explanation when you get it, so I guess trial and error? In any case, the game doesn't really give you anything to tell you that upgrading your leaf is significant, so it almost feels like the game doesn't care. Even a little fanfare would be nice.

Overall, I'd say maybe a 6.5/10. Barely recommend, mainly based on the remaining charm and the knowledge that updates seem to be planned. Hopefully they'll fix some of these issues.

reviewText:
This game does not have any cool, fancy game mechanics or features. It's platforming at it's very basic, and I love it so much.

You play as a cute tree stump named Woodle who are being asked to bring back water to the forest. On each level there are three water drops hidden somewhere on the map, and you need to collect all three of them to complete the level. The only way to defend yourself against the enemies is hitting them with a leaf. You will make them dissapear in one hit, but in one hit they will send you far back in the level.

Woodle carries a bag in which he puts berries into that are scattered around the level, there are so many of them. With the berries you can unlock levels and upgrade your leaf so it becomes better. When you have enough berries you can unlock a cute bandana for Woodle so he looks even cuter.

It's one of my favourite games because of how simple it is to play, and how really cute everything looks. Sometimes you can't tell difference between a good person and an enemy. I like the level designs and the fitting soundtrack. I love the snow level especially. The only negative thing about Woodle Tree Adventures is the camera. It's a mess to control and it often gets stuck behind a block so you can't see where you're going.

It takes around an hour to complete, and it's really enjoyable for that short time. :3
voteText: 13 of 17 people (76%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
With this game, there isn't much to talk about.

Note my play-time, I didn't quit the game early. That's about how long it's going to take to beat Woodle Tree Adventures. Getting all of the achievements might triple that play-time, but that's entirely because they're a fruit-collecting grind.

Why do I recommend it?
Well, it's very pleasant. WTA is a fine change of pace from sadistic games like Wings of Vi. You don't have to worry about dying horrifically every five seconds just to reach the next checkpoint (where you'll die even more). Your only mission in this game, is to hop around and be at peace.

If you're looking for something with a bit more substance, then look elsewhere. I didn't mind my play-through of WTA. If nothing else it was a well-deserved break from the hell I usually put myself through.

reviewText:
Play as a stump,go around and collect berries for who knows whatever reason,when your main quest states that you should be doing a whole different thing,
Classic father stereotype,he is the reason why you are here,welcomes you to the world and the next second gives you a quest which may end your life. 10/10

Graphics - The game is beautiful and cute in it's own unique way, it gives a great vibe of peace and harmony through it's cartoony style. 9/10

Music - The music in this game is one if it's strong points, right next to graphics. The Devs really knew how to pick music and sounds, everything makes the cutest of sounds, mostly the sound of when you are killing the creatures and the sound of picking up berries. 10/10

Cinematics - Well this will be a hard, because there are little to no cinematics at all, but I don't consider this as a weakness. It's mostly just bubble text on a picture, but the picture is alive and moving and the text is bubbly. 8/10

Story - It was well paced, for a 1 hour or so story. But it wasn't anything unique, you are born, go do this and that and try to save the world, then save the world. A story as normal as it can get. 6/10

Content - For the 3 euro the game wants, you will be suprised but it is actually pretty cheap, yes it is rather short and yes it doesn't have anything more than other 3-D platformers. You get a variety of worlds to explore (6) and to live a life of constant dying, because your GOOD FOR NOTHING FATHER, made you do so. 8/10

Controls - This is the game weakest point, it is living HELL if you are playing on a mouse+keyboard, it is not as responsive as a controler. Don't get me wrong, it is still playable on a computer with a mouse and keyboard setup, but on a controler it is a million times better. 5/10 for mouse+keyboard and 9/10 on a controler

Gameplay - The gameplay is fun and fluent, you can traverse everything you see, but at some moments it can get frustrating, mostly because of the games horrible checkpoint system and mediocre camera tracking. When you inevitably fall to your doom, it will respawn you to the nearest checkpoint, but after the 3'rd or so fall, the game just snaps and respawns at the very start of the level. 7/10


Overall the game is not at all bad, don't be fooled by the length or the simple graphics, it is a fun little experience, and if you tell me in which other game do you get to play as stumb trying to save the world, then hat's off to you good sir. For the price you are going to pay for this game, you will get out a changed person or dog, hope I helped and cleared some things up about this game.
Overall score: 7.5/10

reviewText: First, I want to say that I understand that this is a game developed by a single person, I think it has some promise, and I absolutely support developers learning the ropes and trying to make it. So despite the fact that I can't recommend the game, I applaud the developer for his effort.\n\nThe game is a Super Mario 64 / Super Mario 3D Land style 3D platformer where the world is made up of a bunch of connected geometric objects. You're a tree. You can run, jump, swing a leaf to attack... and that's about it. The objective of each level is to get three water drops and get to the end of the level; there are also berries scattered around (around 100 berries per level or so). You don't need to collect berries to finish the game, but if you collect 200, 400, or 800 you can upgrade" your leaf
date: at 850 you get a headband for your character which seems mostly cosmetic
recommended: and there's an optional hidden level at 600 berries. There are 6 main game levels plus the optional level. Each level takes about 8-10 minutes. Personally I 100%ed the game--that is to say beat all levels and unlocked all optional content or unlocks in-game--at 71 minutes.\n\nThe issue is that much of the core gameplay loop doesn't work very well. Your default walk speed is far too slow
hoursPlayed: your default run speed is far too fast to be controlled for precise jumps. The game also never tells you you can run

reviewText:
I wish I had something good to say about Woodle Tree Adventures. It's colorful art style brings back fond memories of classic 3D platformers, which much to my dismay have all but disappeared from gaming in recent years. As much as I wanted to love Woodle, as a game it's among the worst designed, most disappointing experiences I've had in a very long time. It took only an hour of my time to complete, but it felt like so much more with how depressing those sixty minutes were.

Woodle Tree is a very traditional collectathon platformer on paper; traverse levels picking up inane objects to bring back a spirit tree that's grown sad over the disappearing water of the world. Upon actually playing the game, everything instantly loses its enticing charm, reduced to a lesson in how to completely ruin a genre that I hold especially close to my heart.

At the forefront of all these problems is the games camera, which for reasons I cannot understand was chosen to be fixed in place, presumably moving with you and positioning itself as to best allow you to get through levels. This is a bad idea for more reasons than I care to list, the biggest being that it makes judging the distance for jumps incredibly difficult, not to mention caused me an extreme amount of motion sickness (something I've never experience in a game). Levels are designed with a noticeable lack in direction, full of pointless dead ends, oddly position platforms, and invisible checkpoints that neither tell you when you reach them or work as intended much of the time.

The sound design is just sad to have to listen to, with awful sound effects and a soundtrack that is chaotic, perhaps even musically offensive. The cute art design is the only thing I can give scant amounts of praise to, but even that loses its charm when it jumps radically between styles, none of which are particularly interesting to look at or even reflect the lighthearted feel the game seems to be going for.

I'd like to say Woodle Tree Adventures isn't one of the most dismal games I've played recently, but there is nothing I can even partially recommend it for, and wish I'd headed the words of others and passed on it myself. It left me feeling hollow, and sad for the developer who almost seemed to have something at a point before it slipped through his fingers.

It's really no wonder the spirit tree is crying. I would too if I was stuck in this game any longer than I was.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText: A cheap, low-effort, unpolished platformer.  Includes six levels for you to platform around, with the main goal being to collect three tears in a level before you can exit and progress to the next level.  Other collectibles include berries, which have only two uses: unlocking achievements and buying optional weapon upgrades.  The former are useless, the latter are only debatably useful, as many enemies are easily avoidable, and in a worse case easy to dispatch with your default weapon.  To make matters worse, there are three tiers of weapon upgrades you can get.  The first one lets your leaf fire a projectile (to make dispatching the already easily avoidable enemies trivial).  The second and third?  A simple color change, and a different particle effect for the projectile you shoot.  Not worth the effort to farm the berries for them.  Because of this, the game doesn't give you much motivation to actually collect any of the (non-required) collectibles.\n\nFrom a gameplay perspective, the platforming isn't very tight.  Controls are often loose and slippery, which can lead to many frustrating deaths.  These deaths are made all the more frustrating with an inconsistent checkpoint" system implemented in the game that randomly decides to respawn you in a fair location close to where you died

reviewText:
While this game could have been an entertaining simplistic platformer, it is instead a poorly realized shell of it's own idea.
It is incredibly short, the story is non existant. All the UI elements are disjointed and look out of place and poorly aligned.
The controls are slippery and the actual platforming is ruined by static camera angles that are often non responsive. [ie; they get stuck at previous angles and don't update/adjust to the new setting]
There are enemies, but, you're fighting the camera more often.

reviewText:
This is the cheap version of Captain Toad Treasure Tracker.

You are a tree gods child wood thing that eats berries to survive and to grow better leaf weapons or something to find fairy water to save your people or idk. Cute story for kids and people who like talking trees and magic (THE DEKU TREE)

The character is floaty and hard to move most of the time and what makes it even more difficult is the awful camera angles that are nearly impossible to alter or change. The art is cute and child friendly and gives a nice warm feeling, but that soon died down when the gameplay started to show flaws.

When you die from touching enemies or falling off the map you are teleported back to the starting spawn location and in some maps, that can be annoying and tedious when the camerapans down or in odd areas along with sluggish character movement. Clunky combat aswell, once you get 200 berries and upgrade to the yellow leaf, you have ranged capabilities which should be a starting trait, as mobs will touch you out of hitbox and sometimes kill you even when not in contact.

Easy gameplay makes it simple to pick up or grasp for young children or inexperienced gamers. Thats a plus.

For its base price of 3$ I would say save your money for something else of similar value or something in the 5$ range. I got it on sale for 0.50$ so I can't complain.

Personal Rating: 2/5

Dont let it trick you, THIS IS NOT A KIDS GAME. this is a cruel game about a revenge story. Well then should i buy this game?
Yeah man

reviewText:
This could be a much better game.  The graphics are charming, the soundtrack is nicely chill and the lack of stuff like time limits is quite nice.  It's got serious potential, but a few negative aspects really work against that potential.

The first and most damaging is the fact that you cannot control the camera.  In a 3D platformer where it's very easy to mis-time your jumps, that's a quick road to frustration.  Even worse, sometimes the game will change your camera angle for you, making it hard to see a jump that a moment before was perfectly visible.  Add in the fact that if the character's pack is full it enlarges so much sometimes that you have trouble seeing past it and you can see that earlier potential just start to bleed away in a flurry of missed jumps.

The second flaw doesn't directly affect gameplay, but it affects immersion a lot.  That is, the character animation.  For the most part this is fine, and I really do like little touches like being able to jump until Woodle is upside-down.  Charming.  But when walking about the world, I noticed very quick that the walk animation doesn't interact at all with the ground.  The speed at which you move seems independant of the motion of the legs, giving a feel of sliding about which may not seem like a lot but since you have to look at this for the entire game, it gets a bit bothersome.  And to a degree, since you can't really tell speed from watching the character, sometimes it's hard to judge jumps and you're down into the abyss again.

The third is the general lack of explanation of anything.  I've played up to where I was able to buy a second leaf mainly by accident.  I had no idea why I was supposed to gather fruits until I pretty much randomly wandered outside the house for a bit.  I'm not really sure what it does yet, since there's no explanation when you get it, so I guess trial and error?  In any case, the game doesn't really give you anything to tell you that upgrading your leaf is significant, so it almost feels like the game doesn't care.  Even a little fanfare would be nice.

Overall, I'd say maybe a 6.5/10.  Barely recommend, mainly based on the remaining charm and the knowledge that updates seem to be planned.  Hopefully they'll fix some of these issues.

reviewText:
$3 I wish I could trade for a key

Woodle Tree Adventure has catchy relaxing music. Artwork and models appealing to maybe the younger audiences or more oldschool gamers out there. The controls are easy to use and handle, making it comfortable and friendly to play.
The game lacks base and depth, there feels like there is hardly any objective as the game is mind numbingly boring and easy, taking you through 6 worlds with the same mechanics and mobs.
Although the music is really good, it is the same ~10 seconds of music looped over and over, without it changing through the levels, making a really repetative listening experience.
The story is about saving the world with water drops you collect on your adventures, however, this feels like a task that has very little reward and no feeling of satisfaction upon completion. In this world, very few mobs fight back and everything is a 1 hit kill. but when you touch these mobs, you die instantly and are sent back to the start of the level! Your progress isn't even reset, the mobs and items are still in the same place, you just have to run back to where you left off, which can be a very annoying task when your camera is glitched into the floor!
I hate to bash games with only wrong things about it, but I feel I summed up all the good things in the second sentence of this review.

It took me a total of 2 hours to fully complete the game and 20 minutes to speed run it.
I DO NOT RECOMMEND this game as it costs 3 dollars which could be spent on a better game such as the Binding of Isaac, in my opinion.

reviewText:
This game has made me reevaluate my life. I have become a better person. I have become the Übermensch.

After throwing a bunch of doritos and empty mountain dew bottles at my mother as she was cooking me my hourly macaroni, she relented and gave me her credit card for to purchase games on Steam. Being the kind gentleman I am, I only put $1000 on it. But I didn't need $1000. All I needed was $.05.

This game has revealed the universe in a way only call of duty had before. I am but a stub, a branch of the bigger thing, the papa tree. It shows how futuile and yet ephemeral our simplistic lives are. Our tireless pursuit towards a meaningless end, but we must pursue. This game punishes you for losing, but you can not lose. You are stuck in a seemingly endless purgatory that not even Gaben could free you from. The only escape, as it is in life, is to push forward and reach the end, the enlightenment.

Thank you, for teaching me so much. Instead of throwing things at other to get them to do what I want, I smack them with a leaf mercilessly.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings. I want to like this game.
It has a lot of potential to be much better if the dev put in the extra effort to polish it.

The controls are so close, but still feel very early access-y.
Add that on top of iffy hit boxes for enemies and platforms and it makes for potentially
very frustrating times.

Cameras are a bit frustrating too since you can only partially control them.
You can control zoom in/out, but not pan or pitch, which is horrible on certain levels.
Miss any platform and you fall into oblivion. So on levels where the camera stays low,
its almost impossible to see where the holes are.

As a result its difficult to see where exactly you are in relation to enemies and platform edges.
Some interactive objects, that you need in order to get to certain areas, like wind pillars that are supposed to lift you up, don't always work.  Several times I would finally manage to get into them without just falling out the other side (because the character doesn't slow down once in) instead of lifting me up, i slowly float down helplessly...then fall out the other side.

Its too bad because my kids love it too, but they can't enjoy it for long before getting upset because of all the above.
And normally they hand the controller to me if something is too difficult.  I wish it were just a matter of it being too
difficult, but it's not. The game is not difficult. It just needs to function consistently.

Id love to recommend this game because of how close it is to being done. But until the dev puts in the effort to polish out all the major glitches and hitboxes and bad camera, I can't recommend it. And that is a shame.
It should still be considered Early Access. the low price can't save it. It just needs to be tweaked and finished.
If that happens I will gladly change my review.

reviewText:
Woodle Tree Adventures is a basic platformer which is meant for children 6 and under. The game to me is so boring and you just move so slow ormaybe its my laptop. In my opinion i think ur the enemy for u literally attack ice cream doing yoga with a leaf!? Theres really nothing else to say about this game
I give this game 7 out of 10 because the audience for this game is children, not adults or teens however the levels are design good and the berries and tears are hidden very good
This could be a much better game. The graphics are charming, the soundtrack is nicely chill and the lack of stuff like time limits is quite nice. It's got serious potential, but a few negative aspects really work against that potential.

The first and most damaging is the fact that you cannot control the camera. In a 3D platformer where it's very easy to mis-time your jumps, that's a quick road to frustration. Even worse, sometimes the game will change your camera angle for you, making it hard to see a jump that a moment before was perfectly visible. Add in the fact that if the character's pack is full it enlarges so much sometimes that you have trouble seeing past it and you can see that earlier potential just start to bleed away in a flurry of missed jumps.

The second flaw doesn't directly affect gameplay, but it affects immersion a lot. That is, the character animation. For the most part this is fine, and I really do like little touches like being able to jump until Woodle is upside-down. Charming. But when walking about the world, I noticed very quick that the walk animation doesn't interact at all with the ground. The speed at which you move seems independant of the motion of the legs, giving a feel of sliding about which may not seem like a lot but since you have to look at this for the entire game, it gets a bit bothersome. And to a degree, since you can't really tell speed from watching the character, sometimes it's hard to judge jumps and you're down into the abyss again.

The third is the general lack of explanation of anything. I've played up to where I was able to buy a second leaf mainly by accident. I had no idea why I was supposed to gather fruits until I pretty much randomly wandered outside the house for a bit. I'm not really sure what it does yet, since there's no explanation when you get it, so I guess trial and error? In any case, the game doesn't really give you anything to tell you that upgrading your leaf is significant, so it almost feels like the game doesn't care. Even a little fanfare would be nice.

Overall, I'd say maybe a 6.5/10. Barely recommend, mainly based on the remaining charm and the knowledge that updates seem to be planned. Hopefully they'll fix some of these issues.

reviewText:
This game does not have any cool, fancy game mechanics or features. It's platforming at it's very basic, and I love it so much.

You play as a cute tree stump named Woodle who are being asked to bring back water to the forest. On each level there are three water drops hidden somewhere on the map, and you need to collect all three of them to complete the level. The only way to defend yourself against the enemies is hitting them with a leaf. You will make them dissapear in one hit, but in one hit they will send you far back in the level.

Woodle carries a bag in which he puts berries into that are scattered around the level, there are so many of them. With the berries you can unlock levels and upgrade your leaf so it becomes better. When you have enough berries you can unlock a cute bandana for Woodle so he looks even cuter.

It's one of my favourite games because of how simple it is to play, and how really cute everything looks. Sometimes you can't tell difference between a good person and an enemy. I like the level designs and the fitting soundtrack. I love the snow level especially. The only negative thing about Woodle Tree Adventures is the camera. It's a mess to control and it often gets stuck behind a block so you can't see where you're going.

It takes around an hour to complete, and it's really enjoyable for that short time. :3
voteText: 13 of 17 people (76%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
With this game, there isn't much to talk about.

Note my play-time, I didn't quit the game early. That's about how long it's going to take to beat Woodle Tree Adventures. Getting all of the achievements might triple that play-time, but that's entirely because they're a fruit-collecting grind.

Why do I recommend it?
Well, it's very pleasant. WTA is a fine change of pace from sadistic games like Wings of Vi. You don't have to worry about dying horrifically every five seconds just to reach the next checkpoint (where you'll die even more). Your only mission in this game, is to hop around and be at peace.

If you're looking for something with a bit more substance, then look elsewhere. I didn't mind my play-through of WTA. If nothing else it was a well-deserved break from the hell I usually put myself through.

reviewText:
Play as a stump,go around and collect berries for who knows whatever reason,when your main quest states that you should be doing a whole different thing,
Classic father stereotype,he is the reason why you are here,welcomes you to the world and the next second gives you a quest which may end your life. 10/10

Graphics - The game is beautiful and cute in it's own unique way, it gives a great vibe of peace and harmony through it's cartoony style. 9/10

Music - The music in this game is one if it's strong points, right next to graphics. The Devs really knew how to pick music and sounds, everything makes the cutest of sounds, mostly the sound of when you are killing the creatures and the sound of picking up berries. 10/10

Cinematics - Well this will be a hard, because there are little to no cinematics at all, but I don't consider this as a weakness. It's mostly just bubble text on a picture, but the picture is alive and moving and the text is bubbly. 8/10

Story - It was well paced, for a 1 hour or so story. But it wasn't anything unique, you are born, go do this and that and try to save the world, then save the world. A story as normal as it can get. 6/10

Content - For the 3 euro the game wants, you will be suprised but it is actually pretty cheap, yes it is rather short and yes it doesn't have anything more than other 3-D platformers. You get a variety of worlds to explore (6) and to live a life of constant dying, because your GOOD FOR NOTHING FATHER, made you do so. 8/10

Controls - This is the game weakest point, it is living HELL if you are playing on a mouse+keyboard, it is not as responsive as a controler. Don't get me wrong, it is still playable on a computer with a mouse and keyboard setup, but on a controler it is a million times better. 5/10 for mouse+keyboard and 9/10 on a controler

Gameplay - The gameplay is fun and fluent, you can traverse everything you see, but at some moments it can get frustrating, mostly because of the games horrible checkpoint system and mediocre camera tracking. When you inevitably fall to your doom, it will respawn you to the nearest checkpoint, but after the 3'rd or so fall, the game just snaps and respawns at the very start of the level. 7/10


Overall the game is not at all bad, don't be fooled by the length or the simple graphics, it is a fun little experience, and if you tell me in which other game do you get to play as stumb trying to save the world, then hat's off to you good sir. For the price you are going to pay for this game, you will get out a changed person or dog, hope I helped and cleared some things up about this game.
Overall score: 7.5/10

reviewText:
A collect-a-thon game with a cute woodland theme? This must be just like Banjo Kazooie, right?

No, no not really.

Let me explain. The main problem, the single most important reason I did not enjoy this game is because the act of collecting was not fun. Banjo Kazooie nails this down perfectly with a wide variety of things to do and collect, with different missions you need to complete in each level that utilize characters and the environment to keep things interesting. Woodle Tree Adventures doesn't have any of this. There are lots of little problems (which I'll go into in a moment), but this fundamental flaw is what keeps this game from being a must-play.

To put it kindly...this feels like it would be an amazing game on the Ouya, both in scope of gameplay and graphical quality. The sound assets are boring and repetitive, UI is amateurish, the textures are rough, enemy design feels poor...speaking of those enemies, depth perception is a major problem for me in this game. It often throws off jumps, but more annoyingly, makes it difficult to figure out where an enemy is in relation to myself, meaning I often found myself running into them trying to hit them with the leaf and got sent back to the start of the level. This is also exacerbated by the fact that there is no camera control, often with some very poorly chosen stock angles.

Is there a checkpoint system? There's certainly no visual cue for such, though near the end there's a series of jumps made difficult by the depth perception problem, and falling off that a few times I got sent only back to the middle of the stage, not the beginning. No idea if only falling checkpoints you or dying to enemies at that point would have worked, but I certainly never saw anything that looked like a checkpoint.

There's also the matter of abilities. Games like Banjo Kazooie or Mario 64 have lots of things you can do with different combinations of inputs, as well as power-ups. This game has jump, run, and hit, and the animations for all of these are pretty boring. The rucksack, which seems like a really cool idea, quickly wears out its welcome with the sheer size it grows to.

All in all, this feel like someone's first game project where they said I want to make a new Banjo Kazooie
date: but didn't understand what makes that game great in the first place. If you've read everything I've said and think to yourself yeah
recommended: I could put up with all that
hoursPlayed: it's currently 30% off for a total price of $2.09. If you don't mind the poor design and just want your collecting fix on PC, there are worse ways to spend your money. I would recommend it...with some very heavy caveats.

reviewText: Woodle Tree Adventures is a very bright and mellow game, providing a short but pleasant reprieve from loud, monochrome murderfests. It is a safe, relaxing, no-frills 3D platformer with a gorgeous if slightly saccharine aesthetic. The game can be enjoyed by all ages, but balance the $3 price tag against the short length, limited replay value, and control issues. The jumping puzzles demand precise controls that the game just doesn't have, and the antagonistic, glitchy camera will frustrate young and old alike. Nonetheless, I was pleasantly surprised by this game. It really chilled me out, I fell in love with the visuals, and I had a lot of fun for the less than 2 hours it lasted.

reviewText:
I've got a few things to point out, the main one being the fact that I gracefully recomment this wonderful game for all platformer-games enthusiasts out there! Not only does it bring back the ideas and art development of old-school platformer games, the best games of some people's childhood or simply pleasure and destressing times for any person (which are all, of course, pleasant memories for every gamer), but it also has an individual way of becoming remarcable, intriguing the gamers to give it a try.
The story is not too complicated, it's rebellious against reality - which, after all, is the best thing about old school games...they take you to a new world, apart from reality. This game's world is very colourful, exciting and can be quite challenging sometimes.

I also have a strong point to send across the people who gave negative feedback, making complains that don't really follow accross to be agreeable on. For example, I noticed many complain about the camera mode not being able to control. Well, think about it please, if the base idea of the game is to keep it simple and to the point, why would you want the easy" tasks to be extremely easy too? I say the camera mode
recommended: are what really make the challenge of the gameplay be actually challenging. The opposition of these details are what really give the game the perfect ballance - it's not too easy

reviewText:
I've had a lot of fun playing this game, I would recomend buying it only if you have young children to play it with.

I play this game with my four year old son. Every level is pretty freeform, I didn't even know if levels could be 'beat' until I took over the main character after my son stopped playing and found out how to finish them, however, for anyone that is no longer a child, you will find this game very easy, and very boring.

I've spent at least four hours so far following my son playing as the co-op beaver character, I can collect the items for my son, defeat enemies but not pan the camera or finish the level.

I got this game through humblebundle.com, if you have children you want to introduce to 3-dimensional platforming games, this is a great start, especially for only 2.99, I highly recommend it in those situations; you will enjoy reminiscing over the glory days of your first adventure games while they are having a blast experiencing it for the first time.

reviewText:
This game contains high amounts of adorable beaver. You can't play with your beaver alone though. You need at least one friend to play with a beaver. The most realistic beaver simulator I have ever seen. Is best played in the public gaming lounge at your school while your friend shouts his rendition of super mario 64 music at you, then later sends you a facebook message with a link to the super mario 64 theme mashed up with terry cruz (the old spice commercial guy).
Don't believe me? Here are what real random people in a college gaming lounge have to say about woodle tree adventures:
-That is the cutest beaver ever.
-Does that candy corn have a smiling face? That will haunt me forever. Scarier than Slender man, hands down.
-This game really has me stumped.
-Oh No! I lost my beaver! Where is it?
-I don't know what is going on right now...
-*proceeds to shout mario 64 music for 15 minutes straight*
-I can't find anymore fruit. -Dude, there are several gay guys here. Are you blind?

So grab your copy of Woodle tree adventures today, but only if you have friends, because...
BEAVER!

reviewText:
This game is a well crafted platformer that shows the pinnacle achievement of all award winning platformers. It takes all great ideas such as fixed camera angles, no checkpoints (hardcore) and a easy to learn but hard to master combat system. The combat system may seem simple at first because there is only an attack button, but with hours of training and mastering you will be able to perform the sikkest combos such as jump attack.
Every level is well designed and adds a great sense of immersion to it, they feel genuine and there are many hidden secrets such as apples being hidden in a house with no doors.


Finally this game conveys a deep message that is a problem at the core of society, it teaches us that robbing other peoples water and leaving to them is justified as you must save your father. These ethics and values teach us that love for our own family comes at a great price and is a necessary sacrifice, although you could share the water with all the other citizens, why do that when you can beat them up with your magical leaf and hog all the ♥♥♥♥ for yourself?

Under the many layers of content, like an onion, you will need to peel every piece of skin off and discover a whole new world, a whole new meaning of life. And like an onion, your eyes will swell up and tear drops will slowly roll down your cheeks.
-11/10 IGN a truly magical journey that should be made compulsory for all people to play

reviewText:
When getting this game for free from the IndieGala giveaway, I expected a calming experience of being a treestump, running around exploring the world. Now, the idea itself sounded quite decent and the videos were also fun to watch, but after a short while the good idea behind it turned into a rather troublesome outcome.

Where to start... You get pressed out of the surface of earth to then suddenly be the child of a big tree sitting in the center of a place that never was explained. He tells you to go save the world by gathering tears that spend life and water to all creatures and plants. Having said such, you then live on a floating island with the stages sitting inside your house, taking away all you space you need to live... It's not like you'll ever make use of the furniture you have in there anyway.

Having selected a stage you are greeted by music which I found okay at the start, but it turned out to be quite irritating, especially in a stage where you spawn on some beach. The music there turned into a madness of keys being pushed without an end to it, the song ends, you sigh in relief, and there, the song starts all over again.

The graphics look fun and are childfriendly, the same goes to the gameplay. Dealing with the camera though forced me to actually get a bit upset playing this game, as I had a hard time of non-resetting, locked viewpoints after dying. There even was a moment, where I saw a huge stretched out texture all across the screen due to my character being reset without the camera. That incident made the game be unplayable and I had to reboot. You can zoom the camera out, which is a start, but not being able to rotate it and it not resetting to it's original position make it challenging to enjoy this game. To add up to it, checkpoints seem to be placed in a weird fashion, as dying sometimes resulted with me being all the way at the beginning of the stage, which can be a bit frustrating after a while. If there was a checkpoint and you messed up, it would throw you back by another one which could be waaaay back from where you came from. This made things a bit sad sometimes aswell.

The gameplay itself was just okay I'd say. The controls are kept simple, which is nice, but the movement can be a bit weird to deal with at times. Enemies don't feel challenging and you usually just spam the attack button to get rid of them. Some foes also seem to be randomly placed, and I saw no reason for them being there. There were spiked enemies in a big field and I never saw a way of accidently dying by them. They were just standing there, in the open space. Now, who would jump ontop of them without an obstacle making you jump in the first place? I just feel like they were placed there to fill a gap.

And then there you are, running around from one stage to another, gathering the berries and tears you find to save the world from... drying out? He never has gone into detail, and he also never re-appears as you progress in the game, so there basically is close to no story to this game. After 69 minutes, I saw him again, sitting in his old spot telling me two lines of text, then booting me into the credits where I was stuck, even after them finishing, until I closed the game, lovely.

There is a bit more content to it afterwards, a stage that unlocks when you have 600 berries, and items that unlock as you progress with gathering named berries during the stages. Now... I never got to experience what the unlocked stage is about, as it seemed only responded with a white screen, then freezing, waiting for me to kill the .exe.

All in all, I'd say that the game was okay for the fact that I didn't have to pay for it. Same goes to the frame, I like the idea of having a peaceful platformer without any punishment or time-limits in addition with cute and simple graphics. But I was punished by the lack of camera movement, the weird checkpoints that threw me back a lot all the time, and the fact of the camera just locking into weird places afterwards.

Too bad...

reviewText: Cute game for kids with a decent graphic art design.  Nothing sophisticated in the sense of story, graphics, or gameplay.  You are a small tree trying to collect water drops to save the big tree.  You use a leaf to attack any enemy you may face, and if you are hit by an enemy or fall off the edge (which you'll do a lot) then you'll restart the level without having to recollect all of the water drops or the apple looking things laying around.  The game is definitely a casual, third person platforming game.  However, the reason why I don't recommend this game is due to the horrible camera.  There were times when I fell off the edge that the camera would shift a full 180 degrees compared to what it should be.  Without any manual control over the camera, this made it a very difficult task.  Too often, even if the camera worked, it became an issue for the simple platforming sections.  Overall your kids may like this game if they can past the frustrations.

reviewText:
The game is cute, I can attest to that among other reviewers, but the game has a bunch of problems on the side too. First of all Woodle moves like a block of wood and not in a good way, the controls are too sluggish and slow for the stage environments. I understand there may be kids playing this, but it wouldn’t hurt if the protagonist can move slightly faster than a snail.

The camera angle leaves a lot to be desired as well, often times I would be struggling to see where I’m jumping and forced to estimate my landing spot, this is artificial difficulty and pure annoyance.

Beyond the above issues, the game did run fine enough on its own and I’m happy with the amount of content available. Thus for the current asking price, I would recommend this as an afternoon distraction, and it might not be a bad idea to get it for a younger kid either.

reviewText:
OVERALL: Not that good, gameplay feels annoying and sluggish, sounds are also annoying and repititous. 2/10

Controls too slowly, i cant make jumps in a fluid manner. Jumping forward is too powerful, you jump forward at a constant speed but its a speed faster than the walking speed so frequently I fall off platforms and I don't feel like it's my fault that I did.

You control the movement of the character 100%, there's no momentum, no slow down if you jump in one direction and then decide to change directions mid air.

The camera controls badly, i can't look around the level easily to tell if i still have to collect items there - to waste time getting back up. You can zoom the camera in and out but you cant use it to look up over the character or back behind him easily, Like I want to zoom out so I can see the depth better of where I have to pick ♥♥♥♥ up but then it just zooms out - there's no limit on zoom btw it goes out forever if you want.

The attack range is so small hard to see, but you die in one hit. If you hit an enemy he doesnt go away for a moment so if you hit him and then run into him you die instantly anyway.

The item pickup hitbox seems too small because I've gone through objects without picking them up.

It's hard to tell depth in the game maybe partly because half of the object textures are flat colours. There's moments where you have to jump to the side of the screen in the unknown because the camera won't look there, and there turns out to be an enemy so you die instantly - this fills me with hate.

The axis of motion is weird, it seems like it limits you to degrees of 5 around in the circle of 360, and not full 360, so your character jitters around as it turns and it feels bad.

The character's backpack becomes more full the more you pickup objects, so full sometimes you can't see past it.

I wish there was at least jumbled talking for voices for characters, it felt like the music was getting very repeaty, the sound of the waterfall cuts off before it loops again every 4 seconds, it felt like the world was not alive even as simply stylised as it was.

reviewText: This is the best game ever made with the expection of E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial and super man 64 this game is a legendary game about a tree that moves while not the best controls ever they are very responsive if you die its beacuse of you not the game its that good the music is god tier the graphics are Crysis 3 Rival-Like the animations are so good that they look like real life the and my game looks so good it makes my computer lag its amazing the objective of the game is to find all the fairy tears its such a innovative concept the game also contains many platforms the jumping works so well i'd say its almost as good as Mario 64 this game has one of the most interesting storys in video game history the objective is the collect 3 fariy tears in each level now this is such a innovative feature you get a leaf now this leaf should be in games like God Of War or Dante Inferno this leaf is the best weapon in gaming history you might say what is so good about a leaf" well Woodle can swing the leaf to make baddies go flying to outer space its so quick that you don't even see the animation there are many glitches however they a very good edition to the game i ran into about 9 game breaking glitches in the game but the levels whereso well that don't even care now you cannot control the camera however the auto camera is so good a can say this same camera should be a standard in all games overall woodle tree adventures is a adventure for ages a game that is so dang good this game redefines how realistic a video game can get Woodle Tree Adventures is easily one of the best if not the best game ever  i can recommend this game to anybody this is easily one of the best games ever made this is GOTY 2014 just amazing and a very good game 100/100 GOTY 2014 GOTY of all years best game ever made Woodle Tree Adventures is just a amazing game they don't make games like this anymore easily a legend of game"

reviewText:
Woodle Tree...
Is a game where you're going out for the elder tree collecting water for each and everyone...
but.. NEVER BEFORE have I held such broken and sticky controls (Was using F710 gamepad as it reccomends)
the sliding, and jumping makes it rough but the damn camera angle that randomly turns 180 degrees so you're forced to play the map backwards is just insane... I also took alot of printscreens of various maps, showing that theres a fruit that's impossible to get, content never reachable, and the reverse camera (If you have played*) The enemies are one shot each, but with a green leaf you can kill everything but orange leaf (upgrade) you can't kill the caterpillars :I BUT GET MORE CHECKPOINTS INGAME PLEASE

The game it self is aparently NOT early access and costs 2,99€ W/O % off.

Time to talk about the good things.
It's cute, and adorable, really colorful and vibrant and for once it's lovely to see this sort of game with a slight enemy variant, even though it did not change the game too much. The color and atmosphere is just warm and lovingly, and I found my self in the end actually asking for more levels- It's a really REALLY short game.

So overall... I wouldn't really reccomend this, and then again if you're in for a cheap (somewhat broken) platformer well... then this is what you're out for.. I am very splitted by it..


Not reccomended for people looking for a fully working game.
(Honestly thought this was early access)
5/10 but reccomended for the people who are really bored.
-Lyh Flare

reviewText: This game reminds me a lot of the older platform games where the object of the game, just like this, is to make it through a level collecting a particular amount of certain items to beat it. You have a leaf weapon to take out the baddies and a little sack that expands through the level as you collect items needed to unlock more levels. Not the best of games, but was rather enjoyable with an easy going classic sounding soundtrack and some tricky jumps to be made to complete the level.

reviewText:
Things Woodle Tree Adventures does right:
-Cute Style and interesting character design
-Bright worlds with a decent enough amount of variety
-Those block guys who cry when you hit them

Things Woodle Tree Adventures could improve:
-Music is nice but get's repetitive quickly (would be nice to get some bouncier more energetic tracks)
-Killing enemies serves little purpose and doesn't feel satisfying (Most of them don't even try and hurt you and they make no noise while alive or dying. Also they all only take one hit even the big ones. An achievement similar to the 1'000 berries one could also remedy this nicely)
-Collecting berries after a while feels pointless (Could use an in level counter in one of the corners to show how many you've accumulated. Also berries really aren't used for much except for unlocking a couple levels and items)
-Exploration should be rewarded (A lot of times I'd find a secret little area and everytime I'd think it would be great if there was something here even if it was just an extra berry)
-Weapon upgrades don't feel very noticeable (Yes your projectile goes farther but all the creatures only take one hit to kill)
-Controls feel a little slippery and the world feels weightless making it hard to gauge where exactly you'll land when jumping. (Aside from a few clumps Woodle really has no effect on the enviroment)
-Could use more levels
-Boss fights wouldn't hurt


If I had to describe Woodle Tree Adventures in a word it'd be: complex. WTA is a short 3-D collect-a-thon platformer (reminiscent of Mario 64 and Banjo Kazooie) as much as it is a coming of age story. I won't get into the meat of the story but Woodle is sent on a life threatening quest to gather the fabled Fairy Tears and a crap ton of berries all while  trying to prove himself to his Father the Deku Tree. In this quest he encounters terrifying enemies such as Caterpillars, Candy Corn People and a couple really tall guys. There are 6 different levels rich in colour and interesting in design, as well as a few unlockable weapons (Although the don't differ much, I actually still have no idea what the headband does.) You can also bring a buddy along as a beaver to help you collect your berries. On the surface WTA is a cute platforming adventure you can waste a couple hours in, but at it's core WTA is a deep philosophical journey and a look at today's society as a whole. You collect berries monotonously as an allegory for everyday life, there are also underlying themes of surpassing your elders and whether giving up on your dreams to take up their mantle is the right choice.

In the end though there are a lot of things wrong with WTA and a lot of things right I have to give it a 6/10. I hope a Woodle Tree  Adventures 2 is in the works and if so the developer takes my criticisms to heart.

reviewText: I payed .38 cents for this. I mean for that price you can't really go wrong with a game.  It's a very simple concept, and it is also very short. But again, I only paid pocket change for it. I 100% it in just over an hour (61 minutes to be exact) just cuz it was cute. And it had cards and was an easy 100%. It runs well, controls and camera are a bit annoying at first but you get used to them rather fast. So I mean, it was cute and there aren't any MAJOR game breaking problems with it.\n\nTL;DR - It runs, it's cute, it's an easy 100%, there's cards. Just the camera angles and controls are a little meh. Expect an hour or so of gameplay. For 38 cents you can't go wrong.

reviewText: I've only played the first level as of now, and have wandered a bit on the second level. As of right now, I think this game would be wonderful as a young childs first steps into gaming or platform gaming. For older folks, this would either be a cutesy little way to pass the time, or a simple and sweet nostalgic throwback to the very basics of platforming, with a colourful 3D twist.\nThe game is designed with very bright colours and simple geometry in mind, with a very clear resembelence to young childrens media. It's not a hard game, even for a non gamer, but for a young child this would be a great way to start an enjoyable gaming path. You basically play as a cute little tree stump, collect berries, and gather 3 tears to go onto the next level, and it's wrapped into a very adorable, brightly coloured package. I can't wait to see what this game looks like finished, myself. Buy it if you like very simple platforming and cuteness. I really do not recommend for gamers looking for a challenge.

reviewText:
This might be an OK game for children.  It does have a very cute presentation, and the whole game is very family friendly.  Many of the enemies don't even really seem interested in attacking you.  Think of it as a cuter, cheaper Mario 64 Lite.

That being said, if you are an adult I would not waste your time on this one.  The camera is awful and cannot be adjusted.  The control scheme is awful and cannot be adjusted in the options.  The actual control of your character is awful, you have no weight... you feel slippery and floaty which is terrible in an platforming action game.

In short, the presentation is great for children.  The gameplay, however, is terrible.

3/10

reviewText:
If you're looking for a really-challenging videogame for platform experts, Woodle Tree Adventures is probably not adequate for you. Anyhow, this indie game from Italy has its own notable strenghts:

- beautiful to look at, with its charming graphics and very cute places and character design
- definetly relaxing
- filled with very good original music
- nice ideas and mechanics (Woodle's sack, the different weapon/leafs...)

I think it is the perfect game if you have little children who start to play videogames. On the contrary, as you can see from many reviews (and also from this one), it can be pleasant also for adults.

I would suggest difficulty levels (Woodle moving faster, stronger enemies, maybe boss battles...); by the way, the game is already good for what it is.

For the creator keeping up the good work, it's an 8/10 for me!

reviewText:
If there was an in between button for recommending or not recommending a game, I would use it here.

Little more can be said about this game other than it is a decent platformer with a cute art design and somewhat awkward camera positioning. Basically, this is a budget Mario 64, that lacks depth and story. Aside from that, the controls are cohesive and the game is simplistic and decently playable. The biggest problem is the camera, since it often locks in a position that is difficult to see where you are going and sometimes even reverses the point of view, often causing you to die as a result.

As a $3 game, I would say look for a better use of your money. But, when this does go on sale for less than $1, then it might be fun to just toy around with. Drops cards and is an easy 100%.

reviewText:
Quite unplayable!

+ Very nice graphics

- Awful gameplay
- Crazy and script-controlled camera. Damn, in 2015 the player MUST be able to control the camera with the mouse! Come on... And, overall, this stupid design choice gives the player no perspective on the scene, making, for example, a simple jump the hardest thing to do in the universe!
- Repetitive and not inspired soundtrack
- Who said enemies? If those are enemies, well, this is the end of videoplaying...
- Not inspired animations.
- The level design is really bad.
- No storyline
- The objective is always the same. Who needs water? No, I just need three tears...
- Solids compenetration
- No menu. I just need to press the ESC button to close the game. Is this a joke?

Definitely, this is a clear example of how Steam MUST test the games before sell them, in order to give the users only seriously completed and valuable games.

reviewText: A pretty solid 3D platformer. It's short, but (with a gamepad) the controls are pretty tight and responsive. Collect berries, collect all the tears, and then move on to the next level. It's pretty simple and straightforward, and great for a casual experience.\n\nThe only real flaw in the game is the camera angle. It's pretty stationary, though you can zoom in and out. There's times when you really wish you could rotate the camera. It's bothersome the most when you're in an area where it's hard to gauge your exact position in the 3D space, and you aren't sure if the platform, enemy, etc, is right next to you, or a little forward or backward from your current position. You're going to jump too far and off a cliff, or walk behind or in front of objects fairly often. Again, it's a bit annoying and an inconvenience, but you don't have lives
date: so you die, respawn nearby or at the beginning of the level (depending on if you hit a checkpoint), and continue on your way.\n\nIt's no AAA title, but it is a fun little platformer if you've got some time to waste.

reviewText:
Wow....did gamers become what movie critics have become these days?  I read some of the huge....book size reviews before I played it, and I gotta say they are very harsh.

This game is exactly what I expected when I saw the trailer.  I got it for free....and it's $3....So all those expectations I'm seeing from people shouldn't even be a concern.  I got this game for my son and he throughly enjoys it at the age of 9.  Even I was able to play it without complaints.  It's a simple indie game that reminds me of a mario 64 without all the content and no ability to change the camera around.

And yes, if the designer asked me if things should be added or changed, I'd be able to give him a list.  But it would only be to add to it, not complain about things that aren't even broken.  I've played ALOT of horrible indie games, especially recently with all the bundles and such.  This game is 1000% better than a large quantity of what I've played.  So good job to whoever made this.  I'm sure future creations will continue to grow.

reviewText:
Based on my first impressions, I recommend it.
BUT, on one condition;
Pure and simply, it's the game solely for small children (or FIRST first timer gamers). Anyone older/more experienced will find the game boring and simple. I didn't play much of it, but I managed nicely to recognize many elements that told me what kind of game this is. The graphics is simple, technically-wise (cubed geometry, not a lot of polygons, levels aren't big...), as well as conceptually (straightforward levels, easy obstacles, etc.). Story also; There's one intro screen like from a children's book which tells you everything in two sentences, and then you're off on your adventure(s) collecting droplets (elven tears in the game (Ewww!)) to bring life back to your home.
Everything is saturated and colorfull, I actually couldn't manage friend-or-foe identification, cause everything looks similarly colorful. And, curiously, you can kill every kind of creature - the ones that are threat, but the ones that aren't as well. I think the little ones would like it and as their first dive into gaming and platforming, this could be a decent enough effort.
But for anyone else, there's a myriad of problems: camera is in old-old-school fashion sticking to its rail and can't be moved, graphical options are non existent, I had problems rebinding the keys, since there are listings for the same key function (but probably for different devices) which you must guess yourself. You don't know if you're changing direction keys for keyboard, or gamepad, or something else.. move speed is too slow. I mean, come on, even N64 era had quicker movements in simple 3d!
The main character is a cutesy creature which, again, could appeal to the little ones, but everyone old enough to count to 20 by himself will quickly find it boring and uninspired.
So yeah, if you have little kids (school kids not - they'd be insulted), you could go for it in a bundle, or discount, other than that, don't bother.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is relaxing, beautiful, simple, and have a good soundtrack that fits with it. It reminds me some old games with the same style. There are three problems i've found in the game:

A suggestion i make for the developer is that the multiplayer could be actioned with the numlock pad, because 2 joysticks are unnecessary for this game, the numlook it's enough.
For a first project it's pretty cool, keep improving and you will go far

reviewText:
Good looking game, I only played it for 12 minutes. Why?

The controls are unintuitive, and the camera! WTH. So, you can switch perspective fluidly in a 2D plane  - in/out and it changes your perspective in gaem as it does so. This is a game where you can move in 3D space, A 3D camera is imperative.

Also,  The camera perspective keeps switching, without you asking, as you attempt to play.

Maybe, maybe this is a good game, and it seems to be a game about the journey.... and I'm spoiled for games with great controls. I can't be bothered with a game that isn't intuitive to play.

reviewText:
So...I'm a small, oddly shapped person in a turtleneck sweater that's too big for him/her. I run around collecting the tears of fairys to drink. My weapon: a leaf. My goal: drink fairy tears. My enemies: adorable monsters that don't look harmless at all but become little turds and KARATEH chop right through me all while having that same dumb expression. The only thing worse than the camera angling is getting rabies in the middle of the woods at midnight. I tumble around all day and eat fruits to survive, yet I can go for HOURS without eating one, probably because I acrually hoard them all and consue them into my mere inner existance which is trapped in a small, white box with a single door that I'm too scared to go through. A.K.A the fabrcs of reality, the seams of all that seems to be. Did I mention that I MURDER my enemies by hitting them with a giant leaf? Sure, my whole family's lives are at rick, but I just wanna take my time and explore the world a little....wait until I tell you about how I was born. My arms were flailing as I arose out of the ground and hey where'd everyone go?


Don't you just hate it when someone farts in an elevator and it smells really bad, then the elevator proceeds the break right before you reach your floor and you're stuck there for hours with the smell that just WON'T go away?!
