reviewText:
First of all, no matter what is written down below, don't buy this game and wait until 2nd installment is released!
It's not worth it in my opinion, and honestly after a short play I decided to complete this game merely for the easy to get achievements.
What I liked:
- level design
- challenging one or two times

What I disliked:
- terrible camera that is out of control, so it's hard to see the level sometimes
- brain damage causing soundtrack (it's really that bad)
- it's short
- no replayable

So, to sum up. Hold off until WT2 is released, but if you still want to buy it, don't do it for the full price.

reviewText:
Woodle Tree Adventures is the reason nobody should rely on Steam Greenlight for good games. Inticing people to upvote your game with the promise of a free game will surely get you what you want which is that Greenlight, but you will be frowned upon in the gaming world.

On top of this pet peeve of mine Woodle Tree Adventures screams mediocre around the board. The game feels unpolished and clunky, the camera system is annoying and very hard to analyze where you are on the maps. The combat is very bland most enemys are efortless and don't attack, the berry collection system is monitionous and annoying more than anything. Even at $2.99 I would not recommend this game unless you like bad titles.

reviewText:
You know the things Super Mario 64 was known for? Tight controls, interesting worlds and characters, complex mechanics, awesome soundtrack, camera controls?

Woodle Tree Adventures has exactly none of those. The world feels utterly uninteresting and it's impossible to find the motivation to keep playing, just to collect these meaningless items. It doesn't even display how many you've collected or explain what they are either.

Better platformers were made over a decade ago, I recommend skipping this one.

date: which then sends you back to some totally whack checkpoints. Granted

reviewText:
If Woodle Tree Adventures was given to me as an assignment for a game development class, I suppose I would give it a passing grade.  Functionally, the game works fine.  That said, as a comercial project, it just falls flat.  Woodle Tree Adventures begins with Not The Deku Tree telling... Woodle, I guess?  It's never clear on the player character's name.  Anyway, you have to gather-up water drops.  The story is told and then forgotten about, both by the player and by the game.  So clearly we're here for the gameplay, and that's just fine.  There are so many games that are determined to make you sit through hours-worth of cutscenes to tell their terrible stories, so I'm just fine with having a quick summary and then onto the game.  It's just that when you get there, you almost want to know more about the story.

The game advertises itself as harkening back to the days of Super Mario 64 or Banjo Kazooie, and to that respect it's fairly accurate.  Taking place on levels that seem to be inspired by Nintendo's recent 3D Mario titles, your objectives are two-fold.  Collect berries to unlock more powerful ranks for your leaf, and collect the three water drops to bring to the end of the level in order to complete it and unlock a new one.  Basically instead of coins and stars, you have berries and droplets.  Fair enough.  I can dig simple.  The problem with the levels isn't so-much in lack of things to look for, but more in how the levels are delivered, and in how Woodle (I'm just assuming that's his name) controls and fights.

First, the levels.  As design goes, they're competant-enough.  However, the developer rules over the camera with an iron fist.  The player is only allowed to control the zoom of the camera, which only sometimes allows the player to get a better look at the area they are navigating.  This creates a common problem in most levels where the player is expected to navigate, explore, and even platform along a 3D environment while the camera insists on parking as low as possible in order to give the player a strictly 2D view.  This is a particular problem on a level where the player has to navigate up a wall of honey combs, but there's a pit hidden from view behind what otherwise looks like could be flat terrain.  Then there's the ice level with the obligatory slippery terrain, and the player is expected to navigate and platform up a thin line of stairs.  Too far back, and they fall into the pit and back to the beginning of the level; too far forward and they fall onto the ledge below and have to start over; all while dealing with slippery controls because of the ice.  Then there's the problem of only some levels having any check points.  Die on the wrong level, and it's all the way back to the beginning to re-navigate any annoying obstacles (and it seems it's always the levels with annoying platforming segments that have no checkpoints) in order to catch back up to where the player died in the first place.

Woodle himself seemed content to add to the frustrations.  The game's physics are kind of weird in that Woodle seems to maintain momentum, even after running into a flat surface.  This lead to a common problem where, after running into a wall or something, I would jump and find Woodle projecting himself forward despite no input on the analog stick.  This lead to more than one occasion where Woodle seemed to take control of himself in order to find the nearest pit, and back to the beginning of the level (or if I was lucky, to a checkpoint).  The combat in the game is equally uninspired.  There are enemies, and they will attack Woodle to try and send him back to the beginning of the level.  Thankfully, they're also painfully easy to defeat; especially once Woodle gets the leaf that sends-out a projectile.  Not only are they no threat, but killing them doesn't even feel rewarding.  They all make the exact same noise, fall over, then disappear.  By, aren't we getting stimulated.

Normally this is the part where I'd say that the game was clearly designed for children, so it's okay if it isn't exactly game of the year material.  There are two problems with that defense though.  Firstly, the advertising specifically appeals to nostalgia by referencing games from about 20 years ago, meaning that anyone who played them (especially during their prime) is going to be 25 or older.  Secondly, there are just better games that are child-appropriate.  Steam has thousands of games available to choose from, and there's also the option of acquiring (or dusting-off) an N64 in order to have their kids play the very games whose appeal this game uses for marketing.  Granted that children tend to have lower standards, but when games are available that are child-appropriate AND entertaining for older audiences, why settle?

Sadly, I cannot recommend.

reviewText:
Woodle Tree is a pretty good game!
The music is nice and relaxing, the character is cool, and it's just charming overall. May not work for everyone, but certainly works for me.

It's also fairly cheap, if that helps.

It's of course not perfect though. There are some things I think could've been better, but it's mostly minor to me.
Anyways, the game may get some frame drops and run a bit slower in some places, especially if a lot of objects come into view at once.
The camera can also be tricky. This is honestly the biggest issue, and I'm not the only one to notice this, as far as I've seen. Sometime there's little control over it and it may be difficult to jump to certain places and whatnot as a result. Though it's nothing too terrible, and it's still feels very much playable.

Otherwise, the platforming physics could've been a little bit better. As once you jump, you don't seem to have any control of where you land or your movement in the air at all, which can make it a bit tricky. Though, fortunately the game doesn't give you that tricky jumps, so this isn't such a huge issue.
Animations could also be a tad bit better, but it doesn't affect gameplay and I'd say it's passable regardless.

And while this may not necessarily be such a bad thing, the game is a little bit short.

A recommendation besides all this I may have is something like boss battles, and maybe some more moves and things to do for Woodle himself. As it could spice up the game a little bit, but this isn't really required.

I heard there may be a Woodle Tree 2, and I'd love to see that happen. Especially if the developer(s) does it like the original, just with the potential mistakes worked out. For the original though, I'd probably put it somewhere around 7/10. I'd recommend it!

reviewText:
Buggy, short, platformer.

The negative reviews are not being ungenerous. The camera angle on this game is hideous. There is also a mean bug that on certain deaths can flip the view, making it unplayable and forcing restart.

The game is mercifully short for those, like myself, determined to complete every game in their library. Six worlds/levels plus a 'bonus' one. I got my copy free and it is given away often. I still would not wish it on a friend, even for giggles.
The graphics could be described as cute. The levels themselves are not terribly designed. But the forced angle, with only a zoom option, limits and frustrates.

Would not recommend. Shame really, as it would have been ideal for crayon eaters.

reviewText:
Look... I liked the game, But it's not a great buy and a game only suitable for a 4 year old. It was ok, I mean it had soothing music, cute characters, smooth textures, etc. But it has some MAJOR problems. Terrible respawning, dumb camera angles, tons of glitches... but it had some good things too.. Let me break it down for you.

PROS:

- Cute game
- Great Music
- Different Biomes
- Easy game



CONS:

- Bad camera angles
- Broken respawning points
- A lot of clipping glitches
- No good options menu or way to turn on/off music
- Very few levels (beat it in an hour) and alot of repitition



CONCLUSION

For it being $1.94 (I bought it on sale) I don't really regret the buy but I just wish it was better. It's a good child's game but not good enough to win me over.

reviewText:
I loved the trailer when I saw the game in a Humble Bundle. But when I played it, I was pretty disappointed.
The graphics are very cute. I also love the concept of the character and the enemies.  But it can be a bit improved. It looks pretty unfinished. It just misses something what I cannot name.
I liked the levels, not too easy or difficult. And your character carries a big bag to collect berries. The more berries you collect, the bigger your bag becomes, which looks pretty cute.  But the camera mode is terrible. So that killed a lot of my experience in the game. Because the lack of a proper camera and so the view over the level, made it hard to see what I was doing or where I had to go.

I wish there was a neutral option instead of just positive or negative. It is a cute game, but there are a lot of minor annoyances. But it is not expensive, so it is not a big waste of money. It is still fun to play when you have nothing to do. It is just not a game that I would recommend to all my friends.

My rating for the game: 5/10

reviewText: And so it was that I traveled across the floating cube like mountains, Avoiding enimies as they slowly moved towards me, Jumping across great distances. All the while I looked down upon a young tree, As if waching myself, yet it was I who controlled this topiary figure as it waddled aimlesley, as we all do in life. However, my melancholy slow strut was about to meet an abrupt end. In an instant my view was thrust away from the young sappling and into an abyss of beryl, I was alone. No tree like figures, No water based life, Nothing. I was a single mind wallowing in my solice. Yet although sight had lead me away, my other scences prevailed. I felt the wind blow across my bark, I felt my stumps root into the grass below me. But yet my vision was set on an endless expanse of aqua. I began to loose measure of time swiftly, Yet I felt myself grow into the ground beneath me. My consciousness drifted as 100's if not thousands of years past. Until, I heard it. A screech that pierced my ears, yet somehow remained mono-tone, Then I felt it the tearing through my bark, shredding my insides. I tasted blood in my mouth, My own blood, and I smelt my own bark burning. In my final moments, I felt the force of my mass, crash to the ground, then I my corpse was dragged away, as I felt myself drift out of consciousness. The last thing I saw was the Blue Sky, Fade to Red.\n\nGreat game love being a ♥♥♥♥ing tree

reviewText:
Here is my full out review of Woodle Tree Adventures:

First off, what do you do in the game? You play as a little cute tree stump that walks around and picks up cherries and water drops. Not very hard to do, so the game keeps a casual style.

As for the actual visual appearance of the game, it is very fascinating. The graphics are cartoony, but still maintain a very beautiful and eye catching style! You can't find worlds that look like this in other games. The worlds themselves are very detailed, and unique from each other. They may be short, but you still have a lot to do.

In terms of unlockables, you can upgrade your leaf to have more range and power, as well as unlock a cool little headband that doesn't do anything but just generally looks cool on your head. Pretty fun extra feature!

The music is probably one of the best parts of the game. Its very beautiful, and suits the environments very well. It sticks in your head for a while and also has the tendency to really relax you and make you feel very good while you play the game.

And about the camera, it isn't really that big of a deal. The game is still very playable, and the camera is not a huge annoyance factor. I have no idea why people are complaining so much about it, I mean it could have been better but the game is still playable.

So overall, do I recommend the game? Definitely. Its such a good price for such a great game!

reviewText: I tried to get into this since I love 3D platformers. Unfortunately, the camera makes the game unplayable. It gets stuck on things, doesn't reset when it needs to, and you have no control over the camera's rotation. A great deal of the time playing was fighting with the camera since at times I couldn't see where I was going. At some points it was so bad that 100% of the screen was blocked. Sometimes the camera clipped through objects in the world and obscured my vision by seeing the backs of objects you wouldn't normally see.\n\nIf the camera was fixed I could enjoy this and recommend it.

reviewText:
Woodle Tree Adventures is an adorable 3D platformer that allows players to step into the shoes of a tiny tree hero. The game itself is very simple and straightforward. Your goal as Woodle is collect Fairy Tears which in the game look like giant tear drops. Apparently your land needs water and these Fairy Tears can help with that. That’s it -there isn’t much of a story. You also collect berries which will unlock things when you collect enough. The game is also very short, it only has six main levels and one bonus level and has little replay value.

The game is fun and would be great for younger players, however, I found a glaring problem with the game play. This game is 3D as I mentioned, however, the camera doesn’t act like it. You can’t control the camera outside of zooming in and zooming out. You can’t rotate the camera to see where you might be jumping and it causes depth perception issues as well lots of falls. It turned a fun and cute game into a frustrating experience. I can’t even count how many times I fell to my death because I couldn’t see where I was jumping properly, and then where you respawn is random. Sometimes it’s near the beginning or maybe you’ll get lucky and land close to where you before. There also no checkpoints which would help with that, but if the camera worked properly you wouldn’t need checkpoints because the levels aren’t that difficult. While I think a child would love this game I don’t think it would be fair to give them something this frustrating. On the plus side you have unlimited lives so you can keep dying forever.

The things I liked most about this game was its art and music. I kept pushing through the game despite the countless deaths because I found it so cute. The art is bright and amazingly comforting, even the enemies are adorable. All the worlds are well-designed and have fitting music to accompany them. Aside from the simple controls, you can jump, run and hit things, the aesthetic aspects of the game were the only good parts unfortunately. I really wanted to like something so cute.

If you can handle the wonky camera you may like this game, I did but it was too frustrating. This would be a perfect game for children or people looking for a casual experience. My only other issue with the game is lack of explanation on what the upgrades do, I really saw no difference between the yellow, orange and white leaf weapons. The game is very cheap and also comes with trading cards and easy achievements so if you can put up with the camera I say get it but I can’t fully recommend this sadly.


This review is exclusively written for Y.A - Yolo Army, follow the group's curations here!

reviewText:
This game is one of the best out there. In my humble opinion, it is not only a game of the year title, it's also a game of the millenium. It's simply a whiff of fresh air into the PC gaming industry. This game, ''Woodle Tree Adventures'' can easily compete with AAA titles like The Witcher 3, which I simply adore. The only thing this game lacks is a sequel. A bigger, better sequel worth 10 cent instead of 5. Something that will just sweep the opposition from the face of our very earth.

If you have any doubts - don't. This game is all that you are looking for, combined into a gem, a game of the year 2015. The graphics, the gameplay, the sound works... Just... Beautiful.

Rating this game 10 out of 10 is simply an understatement. This game is far beyond any rating scale known to a mere mortal like me.

I love it.

reviewText:
Woodle Tree Adventures is such a cute and relaxing game!

+ You are a wee little tree stump. Your main objective is to find fairy tears to save the forest.
You will also try to collect as many berries as possible. It's essentially a very basic 3D jump platformer. However, the soundtrack, artwork and color palette of this game makes it a total winner for me.

- Yes, you will find yourself falling off the world more than you want to and the angles can be rather difficult sometimes BUT this is a game that feels so soothing that I don't even care.

reviewText:
for 3 dollars this meets my expctations BUT there are issues I find unnecessary.

The camera suffers from locks and odd angles, and cannot be rotated or corrected if it should get locked in a weird position.  I encountered this in games back in the PSX and N64 era, I get it, but it is an issue with cameras I do not want to put up with in 2014.

The jumps are odd, and I can't tell if the wind blew me or what, but I cannot seem to get exact results each time I jump. Runnin makes this worse. The camera makes it even more of an issue.  Can't line it all up right, like the old Tomb Raiders, it feels like you are jumping blindly through these levels.

You cannot really die, and dying costs seemingly nothing.  Enemies are one hit Kill or Be KIlled"
date: the only real penalty being that you go back to a previous place in the level.  No respawning enemies or having to recollect things
recommended: just a placement further back and a long walk of nothing to do
hoursPlayed:
usually because you fell off the edge due to my other issues.

for 3 dollars this meets my expctations BUT there are issues I find unnecessary.

The camera suffers from locks and odd angles, and cannot be rotated or corrected if it should get locked in a weird position.  I encountered this in games back in the PSX and N64 era, I get it, but it is an issue with cameras I do not want to put up with in 2014.

The jumps are odd, and I can't tell if the wind blew me or what, but I cannot seem to get exact results each time I jump. Runnin makes this worse. The camera makes it even more of an issue.  Can't line it all up right, like the old Tomb Raiders, it feels like you are jumping blindly through these levels.

You cannot really die, and dying costs seemingly nothing.  Enemies are one hit Kill or Be KIlled"

reviewText:
An extremely cute platformer game that you can beat in probably under an hour. It's extremely simple... you need to navigate the levels and collect three tears (per level) and make it to the end trigger to unlock a new level. You can collect berries to unlock a few things (a water level, a headband, and three other leaf weapon types.) Collecting berries is also required if you want to unlock achievements.

The enemies are pretty simple.. some will follow a path, some will run at you... although you can't really tell which creatures are hostile and which ones are not. The ones with the happy faces seem to mostly be good.

The camera is absolutely terrible and you can only control the distance away from your character, but it resets in different sections of levels a lot of the time.

The music and sound effects are simple and nice.

It's a super simple game and quick to beat. The level design is quite nice and varied. Visually it looks pretty great.
It's certainly not terrible but might not be all that interesting or engaging for most people. Young kids could get a good kick out of it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: So far I have played the games 25 minutes, meaning the first 2 levels, but it didnt make me want to play more.\nI dont reccomend it for several reasons. First of all the looks. Its a subtle reason and it may be different for others, but while the game looked cute in the screenshots, it looked kind of empty in the final game. It looks like someone had a level editor and shoved a couple of platforms together, added a flower and an enemy here and there and was done with it. It gets even worse through the fact that killed enemys stay dead when you die, meaning that you will jump through the even emptyer world over and over again. But what kills you if there is so few enemys you might ask. Well what killed me was the camera, the controls and the joke of a weapon you have. Now I read through the news a bit and apparently there is a way to control the camera, but I havent found it. that way I played the game with the camera the game set, and that was awful. I often ran down cliffs simply because I couldnt see where exactly I was jumping. Speaking of the jumps- to me the jump felt more like an awkward limp than anything else. I had a hard time reaching platforms that were supposed to be reached, simply because you cant really jump to any height. Now to the weapon: this may actually change, since your weapon is a leave and I saw that you could unlock other leaves later. The starting leave though requires you to almost touch an enemy before you can hit it, with touching an enemy being an instant death thats kind of a problem though. playing with wasd I had problems turning to the enemys in the right angle in the right moment to hit them, the camera didnt help either, with me running into things that seemed far away. All in all I did not have a very good experience at all with this game, its a challenging platformer without wanting to be a challenging platformer because the mentioned points make everything so much harder. Maybe this experience is different for others, but I can only make a review for myself and I would say 3/10.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Woodle Tree Adventures is about an adorable low quality tree stump with arms, who beats unsuspecting enemies (who can't or won't fight back) with his adorable low quality leaf, while collecting pointless, strange low quality berries.
He travels to six similarly low quality, but yet polished and brightly colored, worlds to collect his berries and beat up the poor enemies.

There is no penalty for death, you just have to start the level over, but you don't lose any progress (ie: nobody will beat you up and steal your drugberries). Edited to add: Yes, Drugberries. He's gotta be doing SOMETHING with them!
The berries appear to have no point, except to be hoarded at your little Woodle house so nobody else can have any. Also, be careful going up the stairs. When I was at that 'hub' between worlds, I managed to trip (read: drag woodle face first) up the stairs. It's those adorable, low-quality legs.

I didn't want to judge a book by it's cover, and when I saw it on Greenlight, I thought I'd give it a chance.
Is it worth it? Probably not. Did I get some amusement out of it? Sure. I'm always up for bright and shiny collectathons. As long as they are marginally functional, which Woodle is, I'm in. (Don't get too inspired to jump while in the left-right moving platform on level 1.. you'll go through the floor! And the camera angles? OH LAWD!)

My recommendation? Pick it up uber-cheap and farm it for cards, or if you've got a kid in the house, stick them on the controller for a bit. After all, it's always better to beat on unsuspecting ladybugs, sheep, turtles and other adorable creatures in a videogame than in real life, right?

Edited to add after completion of game: The inability to move the camera is my main pet peeve. And holy crap the game is so EASY. Don't like where you're at? Walk off the edge, there's no penalty. Just collected a faerie tear and don't want to jump back through the puzzle you did to get there? let something hit you, you'll start over with the tear and no penalty. At least it's relaxing. It has a much better soundtrack than you'd expect from something like this.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is only good if you are either under 10 years old, love anything cute and bright or just want something simple to play. Now my review should show you I played on 59 minutes of the game, that's because that's how long it took to complete. I'm an adult male (20s-30s) and still had an okay time with it. This does have a fixed camera and some areas can make it hard to tell where you are, but if you've played enough 3D platform games than you should know from logic what to do next.

The story line is pointless, but again this is a quick game and I'm guessing it is aimed for children so they might take longer than I did and still have a good time just seeing themselves move around in this bright environment. There are no icons around your screen to show you how much you've collect or how many lives you have left (You have unlimited lives in this game)

The enemies are lazily created, some of them look as if they are friends or just creatures as part of the world, but you cannot tell until you try and hurt them. There are only 2 different creatures which are harmless.

I wouldn't play this again, but I purchase this from Humble Bundle and so a bit of that went to charity and so I don't feel so bad.

If you want something more geared to gamers which is just as cute I say take a look at 'Lovely Planet'

reviewText:
Got the game for 0.29€ from Steam sale and it's worth at least that. Cute and fun little game with no violence.

Timing jumps was very hard at times and there was a lot of falling off the map. Fortunately, the levels are fairly short and any water drops and berries you've collected will stay with you when that happens, so going back to the beginning of the level isn't that annoying.

The camera angles can be really bad sometimes. For example, at one of the places where you're thrown into the air, the camera suddenly switched behind the structure and I couldn't see anything. Had to quit the game and restart the level. In another place, after falling and going back the level a bit, the camera was inside a building and I had no idea where Woodle was. Another restart.

Still, despite the problems, it's a fun game and good for when you want to play something cute and harmless. My play time in record, 2 hours, is for one playthrough, picking some additional berries to unlock the bonus level, and playing that and replaying some other levels to get the 1000 berries achievement, so it's a short game (I'm not a fast player).

reviewText:
Getting this random 5p game,  my expectations were that this would be a buggy mess and a complete waste of time, and I was wrong!

What was good:
-The game looks fantastic, its a beautiful cartoony style that really pops out, plus the lighting is simply great, bouncing off the vibrant colours brilliantly.
-A lot of the musical tracks are really relaxing and chill
-The gameplay overall is very fun, gives me a Mario galaxy x Classic Megaman feel.
-Smooth framefate throughout my playthrough (Best Settings) exept when loading the later worlds

What cound be improoved
-Rubbish gameplay elements, things like not being able to effect where you land after you fall, made me die multiple times.
-Terrible enemies, little variety, the main ones are those cone blokes who just stand there
-Awful camera, only zooming in and out is incredibly annoying, it would be great if we could turn the camera 360.

Overall this is a fun relaxing game that for the cheap price its at now is a steal of a bargin, pick it up if you haven't.

I play this game all the time. (Whenever my Oak Tree Family do not beat me.)
I want to recommend this game to ALL of the people who play games in the world as it is extremely fun and entertaining.
I will continue to play this Ultimate game for the rest of my sad little life.

I would also like to recommend to steam that they Boost the price of this game up as i believe that the creators deserve more money for this masterpeice.
Thankyou, and i hope you all enjoy this brilliant game, i have collected all the apples in this game and i have became the rank Master Oak Tree" that is the highest rank in the game.
Enjoy.
Dan Taylor A.K.A Oak Master!"

reviewText:
Have you ever noticed how, in a typical RPG (and, now that I think about it, most games in general) battles don’t really mean anything? How many times have you defeated a miniboss, only to have it stand back up and laugh at you, saying “I have underestimated you! You are a worthy opponent! This is not the end! We shall meet again!” and make a getaway? Think about it. How many times do you beat up Balrog in Cave Story only to have him fly away without a scratch? How is Black Knight able to keep running away after Shovel Knight stabs the hell out of him? How come you black out if you lose a Pokémon battle, but none of the other trainers do? And how does the big bad villain always seem to get away, even if their HP hits zero, so they can reappear in the sequel?

Woodle Tree Adventures asks the question, “What if defeating an enemy in battle always means that they die?”

This might seem quite inconsequential in random encounters, but Woodle Tree Adventures will also pit you against several main characters. If you defeat a main character in battle, they’re dead for good, and the whole story changes to reflect it. Heavy stuff.

But thankfully, as the game advertises, you don’t actually have to kill anyone! The game offers a second option to get out of battles: talking the enemy out of fighting. This involves solving a simple puzzle, almost always involving the “Act” menu in battle. The puzzle changes depending on what kind of enemy you’re fighting; sometimes you’ll just need to give them a compliment, other times you’ll need to survive several of their attacks, and so on. Once they’re not emotionally invested in the battle anymore, you can “spare” them, and the battle ends. You won’t get any EXP for it, but you’ll still get gold. It’s a very unique fighting mechanic!

I admit, after my first playthrough of the game, I was disappointed in the story’s presentation. I thought that both the very beginning and the final area of the game were fantastic, dripping with shocking emotional dilemmas, but the middle 80% of the game’s content seemed like it relied too much on oddball humor and not much else. The game hilariously plays with expectations and has no shortage of genuinely witty satire of its genre, and I found myself amused by nearly all of it, but after the first two hours as I was walking across long linear worlds and listening to dozens of characters try to tell me jokes, I started to wonder where the emotional gravity had gone. “Why is this game making me laugh, when I thought it was supposed to make me cry?” I asked myself. “Where are the feelings? After such an excellent and powerful prologue, why is the game taking so long to show me more?”

Later that night, as I was lying awake in bed, the answer hit me: the game was quirky and lighthearted because I was sparing everyone’s life. I wasn’t playing as a murderer. If you want this game to have drama, you have to cause it. And I think that’s where all the hype is coming from, all the talk about player choice. This is a game about being a tree-hugging pacifist, or a murderous psychopath who kills anyone who gets in the way, or anything in between. You only need to live with whomever you decide to be, because the game won’t let you ignore what you have done.

Though it isn’t the most visually impressive game, and the stage design isn’t always the best, Woodle Tree Adventures has left me feeling that I have just witnessed a work of art. It tried some new and ambitious things and isn’t ashamed of what it wanted to be. It's about 6 hours long; I’d recommend anyone to play it at least twice, just to be able to say that they've made their own choices and seen what the game has to offer. It’s hard to imagine that anyone would regret the experience.

reviewText: Woodle tree adventures is a top down rpg extravaganza, emphasizing top tier leaf wacking combat, and enemy ai on the level of a top tier rail shooter. I have played many amazing games, such as Bioshock, Skyrim, and Dishonored, but I have never seen a stealth system so perfectly managed. If you aren't within 3 feet of them, enemies can't even see you. That is next gen, and honestly I think that the sequel will the highlight at the next E3. I look forward to the excellent level design and camera.

reviewText: This game is actually amazing. I absolutely love the visuals (very charming, and especially cute), and the soundtrack is so soothing. This game is certainly relaxing. I honestly think this game get's a bad rep. Sure, the controls can be a little fudgy (much better with the controller might I add) but I don't think it takes away from the game overall. There are multiple upgrades, and fun worlds, and the gameplay is simple yet fun. I find myself really relaxed during all of it. There aren't any real downsides to dieing, so even dieing I don't feel frusterated whatsoever. It's just overall an amazing game. It's cute, which I have mentioned before, and that might be the main selling point for me since I love anything adorable (and I'm not afraid to admit it) but I can't help but love this game. The enemies themselves are so adorable too. I guess I should talk about the length. So far I am on the 6th world" and if these are the worlds and not the levels

reviewText: I can definitely recommend it on a deal, especially right now for 5 cents. It's quite a short game, I've just beaten it in one sitting. But I didn't expect it to be very long. It's a cute game with bright colors and peaceful (albeit often unfitting) music. There are, however, a few problems with the game. The main problem, which you will notice right away, is how the camera works. It's very situational. It can give you a nice angle at times, but others it'll make it rather difficult to tell where you're going to land when you jump. The second problem, which is the one that annoyed me the most, is this: When you walk or run off the edge of a platform, no matter what, you will perpetually move in the direction you were facing until you either hit the ground or fall to your death. It's a very annoying bug that can easily ruin the fun.\nBut again, I can look past these problems since I've only paid 5 cents. The game gets much easier once you upgrade your leaf, since you obtain a projectile attack and don't have to get so close to enemies. Do check it out.

reviewText: This game is meant for a younger audience it seems and should be reviewed accordingly. Having said that, I am a 28yo female and I still found it quite amusing ^.^ Its a nice change of pace from Darks Souls / Smite etc serious" games. This game is serious as well. But it's comparatively easier.\n\n- The enemies don't respawn
date: they have a decent variety and types
hoursPlayed:
some are just objects and some are aggressive. They are easy to defeat if you get the timing right. There's sufficient time to correct a mistake but they're not so easy that you can keep whacking the attack and get away with it.

- There are check points which are far enough from where you died to still maintain the platforming challenge but not too far to make it annoying.

- The level design is nice. It has different features and the game overall is quite creatively made.

- The camera is scripted but you can move it and enjoy the game. This game requires patience

reviewText: Woodle Tree Adventures is a game that makes you rethink everything Bill Nye has taught you.  Is life even real, am I even real?  You don't play Woodle Tree Adventures, Woodle Tree Adventures plays you.  As soon as you watch the first cutscene you know, that the government is wrong.  Woodle Tree Adventures takes a risk with themes that no other games have brought up. Woodle Tree goes against what all recent game developers have been trying to shove down our throats.  We aren't computers, we're people, and Woodle Tree Adventures gets that.  At first I was puzzled, why haven't any other game developers realized, that we're people, then I realized.  There is no real life. The thing we call life is just a giant game of Woodle Tree Adventures.   It all makes sense now; all the religions got it wrong.  We must travel from planet to planet, draining them of all their fairy water and berries, maybe even get a bandana along the way.  However, as seen in Woodle Tree Adventures, the world isn't a peaceful place. Woodle Tree Adventures has prepared me for the next era of the human race, it has taught me the truth, showed me who my real enemy is. I only have a matter of time before Woodle tree Adventures is discovered by government officials, in the mean time I'll be grinding trying to find out everything I can before it's too late. I extremely advise that you do as well, for it is our future, our destiny.

reviewText:
Completely mediocre in practically every way, Woodle Tree Adventures looks good in screenshot, but is substantially less impressive in motion.

The game opens up to a quiet scene of a tree with a mustache talking to a new anthropomorphic stump. The dialogue is bland, not voiced, and sticks around for far, far too long and is, as far as I could tell from my random button pushes, unskippable. It sticks around for a few minutes at the most, but isn't actually a deal breaker.

What follows is. Being a 3D platformer, the way the character feels is imperitive to a good experience. This stump guy does not feel good. He walks far too slow, and runs far too slow, which not only clashes with the cartoony vibe the game seems to be going for, but seems to undercut itself as a platformer. The leaf this character uses as a weapon feels about as effective as an actual leaf, and the hitbox for the attack is just about as large as the leaf, ensuring you have to thoroughly snuggle up to the enemies that damage you on touch in order for you to hurt them. I also had a problem with a camera angle or two not giving me a very good idea of where the enemies were in relation to myself.

The stump also has a pretty floaty jump and the sound of him running around doesn't match up to when his feet actually touch the ground.

I also had a bit of input lag, but i'm not sure I can blame this on the game or not. My computer isn't anything special, but it's been enough to play Tomb Raider 2013 and Bioshock Infinite along with the vast majority of the rest of my library. I see no reason it shouldn't be able to run this game appropriately.

All in all, the cute graphics and models can't make up for a game that fundamentally feels bad and has such poor initial presentation. I only played five minutes into the first level before I was thoroughly sick of it. Dying also sends you back to the beginning of the stage (unless I died before a checkpoint), and I wasn't very keen to repeat the half I've done.

Maybe this game gets really good later on, but that doesn't change a first impression.

reviewText:
My Overall Opinion

I got this game for free through a promotion and look at the time and an hour passed by! I lost track of time so i guess that is a good thing but i only lost track because the game was so bad i found my self laughing at it.

Some Issues That Need to Be Addressed

1.) You can go back to levels that you have already played to boost your strawberry count.
2.) The fighting mechanic. It is clunky and just plain stupid with a simple point and click that does not go diagonally.
3.) No checkpoints. If you die towards the end of the level you have to walk all the way back to where you were or sometimes the game will put you somewhat close to where you died.
4.) The ESC button closes out the game. Fix it so that it shows options like video, audio, controls, quit etc.
5.) There is no point in the start up pop screen. Never really liked them on any game.
6.) The game sometimes automatically changes your camera angle in a way that you cant even see where you are going to. It won't even let you change it by zooming in or out.
I would recommend this to someone as a last resort.

reviewText: There's honestly nothing to like about this game.  There's no story beyond the usual 'Collect the McGuffins!'  Graphics are minimalistic and childish.  Sound effects are even more minimal and boring.  You only get one attack (can be upgraded, but you'll still only have one attack), and it's one hit to kill both ways, which makes combat thoroughly unexciting.  Many 'enemies' won't even try to fight back.  There's little challenge in the platforming, beyond that which arises from the annoying inability to control the camera angle (zooming is all you can do).  And the only penalty for dying is being sent back to a checkpoint.\n\nMaybe a little kid would have some appreciation for it, but still, there are better kid-friendly platformers out there.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A game that is missing something.

When I loaded up the game, I was impressed by the graphics which reminede me of platformers like 'Super mario 64'. However as I played the game the faults became more apparent...

The gameplay is quite weak. You can walk, run and jump. Furthermore, you can attack with your leaf (which is tiny as hell by the way). Basically your aim is to collect the water droplets in each area (just like stars in mario). You face a variety of enemies which will kill you in one shot when they hit you. A bigger problem is when you die, you will respawn at the start of the area, which wastes time gettiing back to where you were. The camera is also difficult to control and can get stuck on object of the terrain, hence making platforming unnecessarily difficult.

The graphics are nice. Very reminicent of 3D platformers such as mario, banjo kazooie and donkey kong.

The music isn't that great. Aside from no voice acting (which isn't a problem), the games music is quite mundane and forgettable, unlike the nintendo platformers I was accustomed to.

The story is also forgettable.

Even though the graphics are nice, you should definitely stay away as this game has nothing that will  keep you playing.

reviewText:
0/5

After this game I start to think that free giveaways are not enough, they should start paying us for this kind of crap.
I'm going out on a limb: is this a one-man project done for a university course that lasted from 3 to 6 months? I see no other option.
The gameplay is a sort of exploring-world-sandbox, where you collect items in order to get (useless) improvements and advance to the next level. Enemies are useless, shallow and beating them is trivial. The (fixed) camera management is godawful poorly designed, sometimes it gets stuck and you have to restart the game. The entire environment / map / movement is generally bugged.
This game is probably decent for kids from 1 to 5 years old, when it'll get some fixes.

reviewText: I got this game basically because it was cheap for the sale and kinda got it jokingly, but now i really love this game, although there are a few cons such as camera angles, (which you'll see what I mean if you get the game) and also the fact you die in one hit, but it is cool that the enemies do too. But it has way more pros than cons. This is an all around great game which is very original, I've never seen one like this, killing with leafs the enemies are pretty interesting and the worlds are creative and some of them you have to focus or you could fall all the way back to the starting location. this is a game that is good to play anytime and never gets old when you have a goal to get to in it (such as collecting a number of berries). I highly recommend this game for it's orininality, unique game play, all around fun and just the fact theres probably nothing else like it on the market!\n

reviewText:
Woodle Tree Adventures is a 3d action platforming game in which you play as a small Tree stump wielding a leaf collecting fruits and water drops in your backpack to save the world.  It is a game with lively and colorful graphics, reminiscent of many of the favorite games I played as a child on the N64, however that's about where the games charm ends.

Pros:
-Beautifully designed and vibrantly colored worlds and characters which are cute, whimsical and well designed bring back fond nostalgic memories of old school platformers.  The areas seem fairly well designed and are really a treat to look at.  The character designs are really cute and unique.  These qualities present a lush and intriguing platforming environment that you actually want to try to explore.

-Great controller support which implements itself without need for setup.  The preset button configurations are simple and intuitive.

Cons:
-Horrible animation quality, the characters seem to half walk/half glide across the screen, animations are slow and choppy.

-Poor camera control creates problems within the game where you can't see where you are trying to go, or enemies and platforms are blocked from view.  Often times it's difficult to grasp where you stand in relation to the platforms and enemies around you, leaving you swinging your weapon and finding the enemy is to your side rather than behind you, or much farther away than you thought.  This is a real killer as much of the game requires reaching that next platform and when you can't see it, the result is quite frustrating.

-Poor performance causes this game to run extremely slowly and rifled with lag.  You'll feel more often than not that you are about as quick as a snail... and this alone makes you want to close the game.

-enemy death animations are slow and drawn out, however as they are dying they still manage to attack and kill you while you attempt to slink away.

-the sound quality is really mediocre, some sounds are drastically louder than others, most of the sound effects sound like they do not belong in the game and make no sence at all.  The music is ok, but it really doesn't feel like its in the right game.

Overall I can't recommend anyone plays this game.  Adventure/platformer games are all about the gameplay, and this game has a horrble implementation of anything resembling gameplay.  Its so gruellingly slow and buggy you want to ragequit after just a few minutes.

reviewText:
This game is friggin adorable. At first I was just going to let it run for cards but I actually like it.
Is it a children's game? I think so.
Is it a hard game? The controls alone make it nintendo hard. Plus if you touch the wrong creature you're back to the start. If you're precise enough it's not really hard though.
Also you can have a peaceful run and not kill anything if you're into that. You won't get a game reward for it but isn't the moral gratification of not hurting fictional creatures the ultimare reward?

The story is kinda weird because there's obviously a lot of water around so there's probably a sinister reason why you have to collect tears. Those fairies probably poisoned the water to kill the trees and there will be an epic war at the end where you use the tears to summon a dark wizard that gives Woodle superpowers and everything turns way darker and you fight evil fairies. I mean you play as a stump so there's probably a sinister reason why that's all that's left from the protagonist. I'm still at the first level but idk that game looks suspiciously happy. And Woodle only has a dad. Bet the evil fairies killed his mother. Maybe the tears will resurrect her? So many questions. The plot is so deep and mysterious that I'll probably play it a bunch of times to unravel all the secrets. Will update the review if I find evil fairies.

reviewText:
I found this game fun and addictive. The graphics are bright and colourful making the worlds in this game great for kids. The main character is a log... yes that's right a log, you play as a sentient log on a mission from his sentient tree father too bring water back to the world. The story is very simple to follow and seems very reminiscent of old school 90's platformer games (Like Super Mario 64) in which the main character (and the player for that matter) is given a simple plot device (e.g. save the princess) and the story is set up and the rest is up to the levels and gameplay.

The levels are very intresting each with there own unique style, there are six worlds in total to explore as you collect berries, fairy tears in order to heal the world and you chase down the complete set of 8 steam achivements. You can even team up with a friend to complete levels with the local two player co-op mode.

The soundtrack is quite charming and only adds to the overall enjoyment of the game, at times I even felt transported back to being a child and playing classic Nintendo platform games (Super Mario, Banjo Kazooie and Donkey Kong 64, to name but a few, came to mind.)

It's far from perfect, as the issues with the camera will show. As you are playing this game sometimes the camera will go a bit crazy and move to a point which will make it very hard to see your character, this happened to me on several occasions and made the levels harder to complete (not impossible just a bit harder.) As you can see from my total play time, (at the point of writing this it was 1.9 hrs) I has been quite a short game and even though the camera had its issues, I have still completed this game 100% with all the steam achivements unlocked.

In summary this game has some good moments that will spark nostalgic feelings in older gamers and spark new moments for younger gamers. The game is short so don't expect an epic story arc with hundreds of levels, but do expect fun gameplay, cheery music with bright colors and vibrance throughout. It may have its issues but this fun little game could keep you busy even if it is for a short while.

Review Score - 7/10

Why 7/10?
1. Would like to see more levels.
2. Camera Issues and Minor Bugs.
3. Fun, addictive gameplay.
4. Great Music.
5. Colorful, bright graphics.
6. Main character is very unique.

reviewText:
I decided to make a list to show how much I enjoy this wonderful game.


Graphics: The graphics are downright beautiful the Unity3D engine is really awesome at these amazing colorful graphics.  It keeps you playing and never gets boring!  The graphics really exceeded my expectation the graphics reminded me of Super mario for the 3DS or Kirby games for the wii.  The devs created a very nice loveable graphic style that kids and adults will truly enjoy to bring back their childhood memories.  This is what makes the game truly wonderful.

Gameplay: Performs like any other platformer game would smooth transistion from walking to running and just high enough jumping.  I also liked how sprint jumping brought you further really helped with this.

Mechanics: Now this is my favorite the main character Woodle can obtain different types of leaves all with different powers I'm not going to tell you what the other leaves do but man you are in for a great surprise.  It never feels like you're moving too slow or are slipping on the ground the mechanics give you control which is what is the most important in any platformer.

Variety: The amount of variety in this game is what really makes it a nice platformer you never feel like you're in dull surroundings the game has a variety of worlds colors and power ups as well as characters and enemies.

Lovable Characters: Woodle is such a cute little fella, as is the other characters the devs tried to keep the flow of cuteness in the characters but still trying to make things a potential threat

Dynamic 3D platforming from Side Scrolling to 3D: This was the best part.  The game wasn't just a generic side scroller platformer it had multiple sequences of different camera angles.  For example one moment I'm moving like a side scroller and it switches to 3D view depending on the task.  The camera is good at staying with the character and keeping up with the pace of the scene it is truly what gives the game it's true colors.

Closing Statement.

So far I was really impressed to see what has come of this game the devs have really brought something unique and new to the market.  Sure there may be some flaws here and there but it does not obstruct the game itself, I kind of wish it was longer than it is but I haven't finished it yet.  I highly recommend this game, keep up the good work guys!

Sincerely Dark

reviewText: The sad thing about this game is that I can see a lot of potential in it.  The art design is beautiful and the level design flashes potential.  It has a cute and simple concept that had the potential for a very fun, Nintendo 64 styled platformer that you don't see much of nowadays.  If I was an indie publisher, and someone presented this to me as an Alpha, I might have been tempted to fund further development, however that's all this game really is.  It plays like an unfinished Alpha of a game that has a lot of potential.  The level design is pretty, but the game is barely playable.  The game would be more tolerable if there was a working camera.  The camera gives automatic angles, and is absolutely horrid at it.  It makes the game way more difficult then it is supposed to be.  The only control the player has on the camera is to zoom in and out, and sometimes that doesn't even work.  This game plays like an abandoned early access game.  Avoid.

Variety: The amount of variety in this game is what really makes it a nice platformer you never feel like you're in dull surroundings the game has a variety of worlds colors and power ups as well as characters and enemies.

Lovable Characters: Woodle is such a cute little fella, as is the other characters the devs tried to keep the flow of cuteness in the characters but still trying to make things a potential threat

Dynamic 3D platforming from Side Scrolling to 3D: This was the best part.  The game wasn't just a generic side scroller platformer it had multiple sequences of different camera angles.  For example one moment I'm moving like a side scroller and it switches to 3D view depending on the task.  The camera is good at staying with the character and keeping up with the pace of the scene it is truly what gives the game it's true colors.

Closing Statement.

So far I was really impressed to see what has come of this game the devs have really brought something unique and new to the market.  Sure there may be some flaws here and there but it does not obstruct the game itself, I kind of wish it was longer than it is but I haven't finished it yet.  I highly recommend this game, keep up the good work guys!

Sincerely Dark

reviewText: For a game supposedly inspired by Mario and Zelda, Woodle Tree Adventures bears strikingly little resemblence to either. In fact, I found none of the classical elements from the 90's games" and "new interesting ideas." described on the store page. What I did find while playing this was a poorly made platformer with horrible camera controls and nonexistent enemies (unless you count the ones which just stand there and wiggle their arms at you
date: which is actually pretty much all of them). The developer attempts to cover up the fact that this game is lacking some of the most essential points of a platformer by trying to sell you on the "catchy and unique" art style and "refreshingly peaceful" feeling of travelling the game world. Perhaps the graphics style might appeal to some (namely children) but the only reason the graphics are unique is because most other game developers choose to use things like textures as well as models more complicated than your basic cubes and cylinders with legs. It was a bold move (or more likely one made out of the inability to produce anything higher in quality) but for me it just didn't pay off."

reviewText:
I can describe this game in three simple words: Pure. Platforming. Fun. Wait, why would I not recommend this game if I enjoy this game, mixed messages galore! Well, if you are sticking around to read this, I wouldn't recommend this game to an average steam user. Why? If you look at the most popular games sold, they are creations of commitment to spending hours and hours exploring, killing things, playing online with friends to continue the rampage. This game has absolutely none of that, the only people I would ever recommend this game to are those that don't play many games, those who don't really have time to play a game, anyone that that wants a very small game to enjoy or maybe a little sibling or relative who is just staring off playing games.

You are Woodle, you must collect berries and fairy drops...not much story beyond that. You travel through eight worlds to collect these things, in each world are three drops that you must collect. There are a few weapon unlockables, but other than that, this game finds its charm in jumping, exploring, and enjoying the very vibrant world created by Chubby Pixel. As I was playing this, I was reminded of games like Banjo-Kazooie or even Gex 64: Enter the Gecko, it was such a great trip into nostalgia, that I didn't mind that it took me a little over an hour to beat, but in my opinion, it was extremely worth it.

Now on to the bad stuff: the camera is jittery and sometimes in the wrong place, there isn't any sort of GUI and the enemies aren't really...smart. Again, this is why I would not really recommend this game to an average gamer who would rather play something like Skyrim or Dark Souls II. Another thing I want to point out is that this game is much easier played using the 360 controller instead of mouse and keyboard as controlling the character is sometimes difficult.

However, if you are like me and just enjoy small or even have time to commit to some 60+ hour adventure, I highly recommend you at least watch some gameplay footage of it. To the average gamer, though, who has that sort of patience and willingness to venture out to become a Dragonborn, crunching numbers, calculating statistics or wanting to see that KDR ratio on your leaderboard, this game is definitely not for you.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
While it does have the potential to be a family/child-friendly platformer with cute graphics, the horrible camera really ruins it, as mentioned by many (if not every other) review here.

The last update implemented the option to zoom in and out, which doesn't help at all with the angle itself. Should there be an update that gives the player a freely rotatable camera, I might give it another try.
So far I've played the first level, which was nothing but tedious, and I don't feel a need to even open the game ever again...

Camera angle aside, the gameplay itself is rather simple, maybe too simple for older players (I'd say 12+ years old in that case), probably fun for kids, though. I got a free giveaway key and wouldn't have bought it otherwise, though I think it's worth the money, if(!) the camera gets fixed.

reviewText:
Where to begin... I guess I could start with the best part, colourful graphics. Other than that... The game is pretty bad in my opinion. The soundtracks are just so simple and have a maximum of 1 to 3 instruments per song. The sound effects aren't good. The game has many glitches, such as: Monsters killing you after you killed them, respawning at the start of the level even after respawning at a certain checkpoint (no way to know when you activate a checkpoint)...

There's also the horrible, horrible camera angles that the game decides to give you. I had to control the game with my Gamepad + my keyboard + my mouse. Jumping in this game was very stressing, I could never tell how far I needed to jump because of the camera angles. The game has no main-menu and no UI at all. To quit a level, you either have to reach the end of it after collecting 3 tears or close the game, because there are no buttons to quit a level (as far as I can tell).

This game only took me 57 minutes to complete and the story was inexistant at all. That's including the glitches I ran into and the few times I pressed ESC to pause my game... Which actually closes the game. I really cannot recommend this game, it was more trouble than fun honestly.

reviewText:
A game I just couldn't recommend, WTA is where you play as a log who goes on adventures to eat berries and collect tears. Sounds simple enough but in truth isn't.
Pros -
Cute graphics that match up with Wind waker.
Characters are different and never bland.
Gameplay easy enough for adults and children to enjoy.
Even with my basic graphics card it still played well.

Cons -
Controls on keyboard are a nightmare, Yes I know that it says play with a 360 controller but that leaves people who don't have one out, Same problem with castle crashers and other games.
Camara is worse than I have seen in years, Hitting enemies is a pain and getting items is worse.
Enemies don't show much of a threat, I know it's suppose to be a happy world but that takes away any challenge the game had at all.

So just to say
Story - 6/10 Not bad but simple.
Graphics 10/10 I love graphics like these, Feels like a interactive book from my childhood.
Controls 6/10 The control aren't awful but sometimes feel slow.
Camara 2/10 The camara is the worse problem in the game, It's so close that you can almost see the main character's pores.

It's not a bad game but I would recommend you get it on sale or look out for a giveaway. I got this game for free and I'm happy I didn't pay for it.

reviewText:
Pro:
Cute design
Cons:
Ultra short, finished the game and the bonus level in 1.2 hours
Nightmarish camera angles that dates back to the '90s
Overtly simplistic level designs and enemies that feels nothing like Mario 64
Anti-climatic ending (that's it?)
Bad checkpoints where sometimes dying near the end of a level will send you back all the way back to the start
Grindy achievements (3000 berries? Collecting every berry on every level only net you around 750 berries)
Developed Acrophobia after playing this
Actually need to buy 2 controllers to play co-op (keyboard + joystick was viable back in the DOS age... why?)
Weapon upgrades that feels useless (all of them do the same thing so why bother? Especially when everything dies in one hit)
An ending screen that doesn't let you go back to the title without you quitting the game completely (felt like playing a SNES-era game)
Slippery ground physics on the last level + jumping over voids on tiny platforms + bad camera angles = frustrated gamer
HORRIBLE CAMERA ANGLES!!
Seriously don't get this for your kids unless you feel like torturing them with the camera angles.

reviewText: Alright game. Cute main character and world. Camera is the worst in history, as you can't move it and it gets stuck at terrible angles and gets you killed. One time I restarted at a checkpoint and it was facing a different way than it was supposed to so I couldn't progress in the level because I couldn't see and had to restart the level. No way to rebind keys. No main menu or way to exit besides completely exiting game or alt f4'ing. Platforming doesn't feel as responsive as it could and just feels a bit off. Game takes about 45 min to complete, which is way too short. Also checkpoints make no sense as a lot of times if you miss a jump you have to start back at beginning of level but sometimes you start closer up but for no apparent reason. One time I respawned closer, died at the exact same part, and then respawned at the start of the level, which made no sense because I had just died in this same spot and spawned much closer. 6.5/10. Try it out with caution.

reviewText:
If I were a kid I would enjoy it cuz I'm that kind of guy enjoy everything new to me...But I've played all Super Mario series so that I'm not fond of this unpolished game anymore.

It's an adventure-like platformer with horrible graphics(game released in 2014, not 2004) and bad level design. It has a catchy name makes me thinking about adventure but I'm frustrated with its camera view and enemies in the game. Also with that weird jump animation I'd like to say that it's good for oldschool punks.

Then here comes a paradox: If it's a game for kids, will they feel bored when they face the overpowering mobs? If it's a game for elder audience, will they play it ever?

So that's why they gave out this game as free.

reviewText:
Maybe the worst game I've played this year. It looks cute and stuff, but playability is nowhere to be found.

The goal of the game is not clear, at the begining your father/fake Deku tree explains that you must pick up fairy tears, but nothig seems to happen when you do so, and there is no tear counter or something. On addition, there is no way to quit a level; you either close the game or stay in the level forever (or if there is a way, I have not been capable to figure it out). If that was not enough, the point of view spins randomly, making the game almost imposible to play at some points.

However, if you can get it for free or as part of a good bundle, it has only six cards so you can score an easy badge.

________

Tal vez el peor juego que he probado este año. Es bonito y tal, pero la jugabilidad brilla por su ausencia.

El objetivo no está claro, al principio tu padre/falso árbol Deku explica que hay que conseguir lágrimas de hada, pero parece que no pasa nada cuando lo haces y no hay contador de lágrimas ni nada parecido. Además, no hay manera de salir del nivel que estés jugando; o te quedas en él para siempre o cierras el juego (o si la hay, yo no he sido capaz de descubrirla). Por si era poco, la cámara gira aleatoriamente, haciendo algunas partes prácticamente imposibles de jugar.

De todos modos, si lo consigues gratis o en un bundle interesante, sólo tiene seis cromos así que es una insignia bastante fácil de conseguir.

reviewText: I've played two of the however many levels of the game, and I have to say - I don't get what all the hate is about. It's a cute little platformer that doesn't try to reinvent the genre. The story is that you were brought to life specifically to collect Fairy Tears and bring water to a land - the Fairy Tears acting as your MacGuffin, like the crystals in a Crash game. You collect them throughout simple platforming levels that are surprisingly long, but never overstay their welcome. Along the way, you pick up Wumpa fr-, err, berries, which serve as sort of a score/unlockable counter - every so often, you unlock a new item for your little Deku Scrub. There also seem to be a level that requires 600 berries, but I'm not sure how grindy getting that is. The game overall is rather easy, however; enemies serve little to no threat, and the platforming is simple. The thing that's most likely to kill you is the camera screwing up because you backtracked. To fix a camera screw up, you just go past the point you were just at - but it's still irritating. So far, I give it a 6.5/10, another .5 if it gets a controllable camera. The June 29th update claims you have camera control, but it's not distance that's the problem, it's angle. The price is right, as it seems like a rather short game.

reviewText: Perfect for what it's supposed to beWoodle Tree Adventures isn't trying to be the next Super Meat Boy, or Thomas Is Alone, all it is is a simple story about a little tree stump-like creature, who is created by a world tree-type being to effectively water the world with magical fairy tears. It's a fairly aesthetically pleasing game, with nice graphics and simplistic world design, but the large worlds that facilitate a fair bit of exploration are enjoyable to play through. The gameplay primarily consists of exploring and jumping puzzles, with enemies not really doing much, but making the world seem more lively. It is extremely hard to be killed" unless you run off the world. Coming from someone who plays the likes of Skyrim and Assassin's Creed
date: Woodle Tree Adventures isn't something I'd play constantly and invest hours into
recommended: but it's good for a few hours of time killing or relaxation
hoursPlayed: and it would be perfect for young children as a simple but engaging game. It is worth what you pay for it (2.99 at time of writing) if you want something simple to relax with or for a younger child to play with
voteText: but don't expect a massive game. DISCLAIMER: I received a copy of this game as part of a free promotion."

reviewText: Alright game. Cute main character and world. Camera is the worst in history, as you can't move it and it gets stuck at terrible angles and gets you killed. One time I restarted at a checkpoint and it was facing a different way than it was supposed to so I couldn't progress in the level because I couldn't see and had to restart the level. No way to rebind keys. No main menu or way to exit besides completely exiting game or alt f4'ing. Platforming doesn't feel as responsive as it could and just feels a bit off. Game takes about 45 min to complete, which is way too short. Also checkpoints make no sense as a lot of times if you miss a jump you have to start back at beginning of level but sometimes you start closer up but for no apparent reason. One time I respawned closer, died at the exact same part, and then respawned at the start of the level, which made no sense because I had just died in this same spot and spawned much closer. 6.5/10. Try it out with caution.

reviewText:
Maybe the worst game I've played this year. It looks cute and stuff, but playability is nowhere to be found.

The goal of the game is not clear, at the begining your father/fake Deku tree explains that you must pick up fairy tears, but nothig seems to happen when you do so, and there is no tear counter or something. On addition, there is no way to quit a level; you either close the game or stay in the level forever (or if there is a way, I have not been capable to figure it out). If that was not enough, the point of view spins randomly, making the game almost imposible to play at some points.

However, if you can get it for free or as part of a good bundle, it has only six cards so you can score an easy badge.

________

Tal vez el peor juego que he probado este año. Es bonito y tal, pero la jugabilidad brilla por su ausencia.

El objetivo no está claro, al principio tu padre/falso árbol Deku explica que hay que conseguir lágrimas de hada, pero parece que no pasa nada cuando lo haces y no hay contador de lágrimas ni nada parecido. Además, no hay manera de salir del nivel que estés jugando; o te quedas en él para siempre o cierras el juego (o si la hay, yo no he sido capaz de descubrirla). Por si era poco, la cámara gira aleatoriamente, haciendo algunas partes prácticamente imposibles de jugar.

De todos modos, si lo consigues gratis o en un bundle interesante, sólo tiene seis cromos así que es una insignia bastante fácil de conseguir.

reviewText:
at the heart, it is a satisfying gaming experience for the most part that is worth a few hours of your time for the very easy 100 percent achievements, and trading cards being a nice bonus.

the devs(or whoever made the decision) to include STEAM trading cards and achievements made a good idea as people like me would have never looked at it otherwise, even as a free gift from indie gala (thank you indie gala)

the sound design in the game is the best part. nice satisfying noises, great music.
the game recommends you use a gamepad, and I do too. it doesn't feel good on a keyboard at all. the very frustrating and inconsistant camera are easier managed on a gamepad for some reason. Keys are bindable though. You can do a 2 player deal as well if you have a small child that would like this kind of game. Don't make an adult sit down with you though. That'd be cruel.

its a decent platformer as in its not bad. its just not original. nothing about the game is original. its hardly even an adventure, with just a few stages and no connection between things. barest of bones narrative. and to be frank, very lame art/world/character design. only controls are to move, jump, run, adjust the camera's closeness to you (its not a camera you can rotate) and weakly swing a leaf (your one and only move that isn't simply moving your character around the level) there really isn't a difficulty to speak of. a 5 year old could play this game to completion.

my only real gripe is the inconsistant and uncooperative camera. also the overall art design really seems like it was made by one teenager with ambitions to go into game development, which in combination with the lack of other game elements warrents very little of your time. however i do immensely recommend it if you are after easy achievements. I have them all with the playtime shown in my review.
At 2.99, I wouldn't recommend this game. At .50 cents or free , i can.

reviewText:
I heard about Woodle Tree through the likes of Indie Game Battle (as I also have a character playable in that game), so much to my craving for 3D platformers, I got curious about this title and gave it a shot. Basically, there were things I liked about it and things I didn't, but I THINK there is just enough for me to say the good outweighs the bad. Nevertheless, I always feel the need to explain everything in detail. After all, this game's getting a sequel soon, and it's best there's improvements to be made for it.

One thing that stuck out for me was the visual style. I kinda have a soft spot for it. It has a homemade feel to it, with a hint of Nintendo 64. The levels also drive home a sense that feels much like Super Mario 3D Land. As this adorable little tree log, you simply have to get to the end of each level, while collecting three floating water drops along the way for each. It's simple, but cozy. For the most part, anyway. I do wish the soundtrack was more upbeat and catchy, but the platforming is fairly enjoyable, and your attack has decent range, making for enemy kills to be reasonably tangible.

Not as reasonable is when Woodle Tree gets hit. For some reaosn, the checkpoint system seems to only work when Woodle Tree falls off a ledge; when you get hit by an enemy, you instantly have to start AT THE BEGINNING OF THE LEVEL. Granted, you have infinite lives and still have track of the water drops collected, but why can't I always start off at a portion of the level regardless of how I died? The control is also not the most intuitive it could have been. For some reason, you can't run and jump when moving up or down, nor can you do diagonal jumps. The control issues definitely need fixing up. To a lesser extent, there's the camera. I'm not as bothered by its clunkiness as everyone else was, but it can still be glaring for a game like this.

Lastly, the game is over quickly and abruptly. I beat it in almost an hour's worth of game time, and while I'm the kind of guy that doesn't mind a short game (especially when the price is as low as it is), I was expecting at least an hour or two more than there was. And it wasn't like there was a boss battle or anything to close the game with; it just...threw an ending screen and that was it.

So yeah, this is definitely a flawed game. I wouldn't even really call it a great game, but I still at least recommend it if you can spare a few bucks for a small dose of indie 3D platforming.............Just as long as you can deal with the control and checkpoint issues.

reviewText:
Product received for free

♥ I have severe anxiety and find this game so relaxing to play!

I like it how you can play it for five minutes or an hour without feeling pressure to finish the level or defeat a boss. Those kinds of games are great but if you want to play something for a few minutes, this game is perfect!

♥ The graphics are absolutely adorable.

I appreciate that the colors and scenery are easy on the eyes. There's no harsh neons, flashing lights, etc.

♥ The levels are easy to understand.

I'm a huge fan of puzzle games like Nancy Drew but find that sometimes my brain needs a break! I like how the berries aren't hard to find, they aren't ever hidden too well. Just a fun game to pass the time with.

✘ As other reviewers have mentioned, the camera can be a bit wonky.

I have horrendous motion sickness and the camera constantly switching angles doesn't help with that. However I don't find the camera situation a deal breaker, especially since I tend to play the game for short amounts of time.

✘ I despise the monsters that rush at you.

You can bop them with your leaf but if you're too slow, you have to restart from the beginning or a certain check point. It drives me batty!

✘ Sometimes jumping can be hard to do.

It may just be me however there are some times when I find it hard to measure the jumps - I'll miss the next block and fall inbetween, slip from the edge when pressing the jump key, etc. However overall I really do enjoy this game - it never fails to put me in a cheerful mood. : D

reviewText:
This could have been an OK game for little kids if done in 2D. The spectacularly poorly executed attempt at 3D graphic did way more harm than good.

Most of the time the camera is stuck at such a curious angle that makes it downright impossible to see what is in front of you. Other times, you CAN see where you're going, but you have no way to see what's to the left or to the right.
At the rare moments when the camera sets itself in a reasonable position, it still somehow manages to completely screw your depth perception.

And then you press [ESC] and the game quits to desktop, because the creators never heard of a menu screen.
