reviewText:
Woodle Tree Adventures
Rating: 3/10

This is the story of a little tree that goes water-drop hunting for his father. He has to jump and defeat enemies to get to the drops and deliver them at the end of the level where they are put in plastic cups.

The game looks kinda cute, and that's the only positive point really about it (oh, it is dead cheap and you can get it for free at the time of writing). It plays horrible with a fixed point camera that tries to give a nice view but often fails so you really can't see where you are going. You really need to play this with and xbox controller, and then often you are struggling not to fall off the level.

You also encounter different enemies which you can beat by hitting them with your leaf. Which plays and looks really goofy and doesn't add up to a better gaming experience.

I completed the first level and started the second so I didn't see really much of the game but I think it will not improve a lot.

Nice try to create a Nintendo-like game but it really fails to do. Avoid playing this, just collect the cards...

reviewText:
I got this game for free, and I sincerely think you should only get this game if you have the same opportunity.

If you really, really like platformers, you MAY like this game, however, there are countless other platformers for you to enjoy instead of this. I try really hard not to give a thumbs down review, but I just can't avoid it with this game.

The aesthetics are good - very simple, colorful environments. The music is nothing fancy, but appropriate for the simple gameplay.

The controls are very simple and easy to learn, the learning curve is pretty minimal if non-existent. The only real difficulty comes from the camera being fixed, you can only zoom in and out at a weird angle, however, you do this by moving the mouse back and forth (even though, intuitively it would be more ergonomic to use the mouse wheel for this function). I tried experimenting with the keyboard and mouse to turn/pan the camera, but it is indeed fixed for the game. The worst part, is that there are areas in the game where the camera will orient a different way, and if you die it will remain fixed in the new orientation, potentially making it even more difficult to navigate through the map. There also does not seem to be a checkpoint system, so everytime you die by touching an enemy or falling off the stage you have to restart from the very beginning of the area.

You play as a little tree stump and have to collect fairy water drops(?) and these floating orbs that you store in your pouch. The purple pouch gets bigger as you collect more orbs, and I thought this was a nice touch.

The game plays super casually and is not very challenging - you hit enemies with a leaf to destory them.

As a platformer, the game is kind of boring, and the story is not very engaging - a master tree created you to give water to the land (and that's about it).

I usually don't mention the game price if I think the gameplay (and everything else about it) outshines its price tag. That being said, this game currently costs $2.99, and I don't think you should bother getting it even if it was free (except maybe for the cards).

Do not recommend.

reviewText:
Main problem: Hindering camera with no input options other than zoom in or out.

It's too hard to control or see to control where you are and where your character is, usually floating past where you intended to land a jump and off the edge of the level... for to 40th time.  Falling means going back to a nearby checkpoint (as does touching most enemies), which isn't a terrible punishment, but there's nearly no learning curve since all jumps feel blinded by pre-determined camera perspective.

This game has some hints of cute platform fun (Mario 64 style), but primarily the camera needs more work before it's worth giving it a try.  Thankfully, this game has recently been updated and is likely to see more improvements.

reviewText:
I got this game for free, and I sincerely think you should only get this game if you have the same opportunity.

If you really, really like platformers, you MAY like this game, however, there are countless other platformers for you to enjoy instead of this. I try really hard not to give a thumbs down review, but I just can't avoid it with this game.

The aesthetics are good - very simple, colorful environments. The music is nothing fancy, but appropriate for the simple gameplay.

The controls are very simple and easy to learn, the learning curve is pretty minimal if non-existent. The only real difficulty comes from the camera being fixed, you can only zoom in and out at a weird angle, however, you do this by moving the mouse back and forth (even though, intuitively it would be more ergonomic to use the mouse wheel for this function). I tried experimenting with the keyboard and mouse to turn/pan the camera, but it is indeed fixed for the game. The worst part, is that there are areas in the game where the camera will orient a different way, and if you die it will remain fixed in the new orientation, potentially making it even more difficult to navigate through the map. There also does not seem to be a checkpoint system, so everytime you die by touching an enemy or falling off the stage you have to restart from the very beginning of the area.

You play as a little tree stump and have to collect fairy water drops(?) and these floating orbs that you store in your pouch. The purple pouch gets bigger as you collect more orbs, and I thought this was a nice touch.

The game plays super casually and is not very challenging - you hit enemies with a leaf to destory them.

As a platformer, the game is kind of boring, and the story is not very engaging - a master tree created you to give water to the land (and that's about it).

I usually don't mention the game price if I think the gameplay (and everything else about it) outshines its price tag. That being said, this game currently costs $2.99, and I don't think you should bother getting it even if it was free (except maybe for the cards).

Do not recommend.

reviewText:
Cons:
1. Very bad story, actually no story
2. Camera, very very bad field of view.
3. Checkpoints. When you die, you spawn near spawn place, if you die again it return you to start of a map
4. For this simple game too much system requirements, low FPS for old graphic cards
5. You can't turn off sound if you run this on WinXP or older, so annoying
6. If you start again game while you were in middle of game, you spawn with green leaf
7. Enemies are so stupid and you don't represent any threat

Pros:
......

Don't buy this game, if you got this already grab 3 cards and go away

2/10

reviewText:
As I am a bit of an achievement hunter, I love to 100% games. But this game... Boy oh, boy. This game is bad

I got it for free, so I guess I shouldn't complain but, I will.
This game is very much like an old PS1 game, but the controls, in my opinon, are awful. The platforming is so unfair, making you make the impossible jumps just so you can collect that on last berry that you need to 100% the level. That's not even the worse part. The worst part is that when you even try to 100% a level, you still have to redo it, over and over to get the berries for those two f'ing achievements. This game is just something you should buy for a friend you hate, but don't want to let them down.

So, would I recommend this game? No. Unless you want to blow some cash on a game that feels like it could be a flash game.

I give this game a 4.7/10. Playable to the slightest point, but would not recommend it.

reviewText:
I got this game for free, and I gotta say I'm not /totally/ disappointed.
The games not good. Really, who'dve guessed, but it's not really why you'd think.
You look at the game and it looks like some animation studen't fist product
It's got cutsey, simple graphics, it's a grab the key to open the door type platformer but that's not why it's not good.
It's not good because it doesn't feel rewarding
I see no reason to grab these enormous berries(?) other than to fill my sack.
The level design was alright but the enemies felt apathetic, like they wanted to attack but couldn't
Also the lack of UI for the berries(?) to show your progress on a level by level basis should have been added.

So yeah, no. Money could be better spent elsewhere.

reviewText:
The Good:
+Pretty visuals
+Woodle is cute
+Peaceful Music
+Local Co-Op

The Bad:
-Camera is a problem (post patch)
-Art style makes it difficult to distinguish ground from wall
-Not much to do
-Gameplay feels mindless
-Scarce checkpoints/pointless repetition
-Slow gameplay

It's a good game for kids, but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone outside of that age group. There's just no real substance to this game. You collect berries and three tears to get through levels. That's it.

On a more technical standpoint, the levels are pretty, but dull. Almost all of the enemies in the game world feel out of place within, with a few exceptions. The art style and camera make it difficult to judge distances, which is a killer in platforming games. If you misjudge the distance of the jump, then you are almost guaranteed to restart from the beginning, as checkpoints are scarce (note, this review was written AFTER the camera patch that is advertized on the front page).

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I bought this game for 5 euro cents.
Review: This game is just bad. At first I saw some potential in it because the art style seemed interessting.But then I actually started playing the game. The first major issue is that you do not control your own camera angle. Often times I was stuck somewhere just because the camera chose the most inappropriate angle for the situation.
Secondly, the controls are extremely clunky almost to the point where the game is completely unplayable. What's more the game displays the depth pretty inaccurately. At some points I couldn't make a jump because I thought i was at the same level as the platform (although this may be caused by the poor camera angles).
The game just feels unfinished. I am really sad to say this, as I saw some potential in it. The only redeeming factor for this game is that you can make a profit from the trading cards(because it is 5 cents as of writing this review). Other than that there is no real purpose of buying it.

reviewText: Art style is simple but nice to look at and works well for this style of game. The game is short but I think for the price it is not an issue. My only major complaint is that the checkpoint system seems completely random. There is no visual indication of when a checkpoint is reached and whether or not you spawn there or at the beginning of the level seems completely random also. Overall, not a bad game for the price and I enjoyed playing it.
